titleStmt.title: The Feign'd astrologer a comedie.
titleStmt.author: Calderón de la Barca, Pedro, 1600-1681. Astrologo fingido.
Corneille, Thomas, 1625-1709. Feint astrologue.

notesStmt.note: Reproduction of original in Huntington Library.
As adaption by an unknown translator of Thomas Corneille's "Le feint astrologue," which was founded on Calderon's "El astrologo fingido."

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: LONDON, Printed for Thomas Thornycroft, at the Eagle and Child, near Worceſter-houſe in the Strand. 1668.

list.item: SIr Chriſtopher Credulous—A Rich old Knight, father to Clarinda.
Bellamy—In Love with Clarinda, and belov'd by Celia.
Lewis Bernard—Friends to Endimion, and Gratian.
Celia—In Love with Bellamy, and belov'd by Gratian.
La-gripe—An old French man, a ſervant of Sr Chriſtopher's.
Shift Rawman—Two wittie Knaves ſervants to Endimion.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: HOw ſtrangely does thy News perplexme, Shift?
Art ſure 'tis true?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Beatrix tells me ſo, and then I muſt believe it.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Is ſhe your Oracle then?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: But is it poſſible that my Clarinda ſhould—

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: No, that it is not, ſhe ſhould ever love,
You I mean; for there may be perhaps—

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Nay, nay, I gueſs the reaſon of her ſcorn,
She loves elſe where.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: E'en like enough.
She'd ne'r hold her ſelf at ſo high a rate to you,
Had ſhe not other Chapmen.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: I ſmelt ſome ſuch thing in a certain Conference, I had with my Princeſs to'ther day; and had not her doting old Maſter come by i'th nick and ſpoilt our ſport, I was within two kiſſes of all her Miſtreſſes ſecrets.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Is Beatrix ſuch a tell-tale?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Tell-tale, and Wag-tail. Why, is ſhe not a Woman? and is that Sex made for Privy Councellors? 'tis true, Chambermaids, I think take an oath of Secreſie as they do; and might do well to keep it too, as ſome of the others do: but alas!—

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Saving your mock-Morals and mongrel-Comments
On the whole Tribe, tell me of Beatrix, Sir,
What of her? what ſays ſhe?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: What ſays ſhe? why ſhe ſays any thing; ſhe can no more keep a ſecret than another woman, ſhe is no more able to digeſt it; 'twill up Sir, 'twill up when occaſion ſerves.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Let Shift alone to mannage her Evidence,
He'l pump her drie, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Sure enough: for whether it be my Perſon, my nimble dapper Perſon; or my Wit, my fooling Wit ſhe's taken with, or talking humour, in which we moſt Sympathize, I know not: but I'm ſure, I taſte more of her kindneſs then you do of her Miſtreſſes:
However, our way of Love is nothing troubleſome, tis free, and without any tye, we aim not at Hymen, we; as long as we like one another, ſo; when we are weary; ſo.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: A pretty modern Method.
sp.p: But prethee tell me Endiminion, art not thou ſick of thy Conſtancy? haſt not lov'd Clarinda long enough? to every fair one you were wont to cry, I love you; and ſcarce a whole day lov'd the ſame.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: And yet Clarinda now with all her ſcorn
Has held him to't a Month;
'Tis a ſtrange Metamorphoſe in your Worſhips humour.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I break cuſtome, I confeſs it, for Clarinda's ſake:
Yet let it not amaze thee, Bernard,
To ſee me burn ſo long in the ſame flames;
For if Love at firſt made me her Servant,
That Love is now to a Gaprichio vaniſht,
A meer peeviſh obſtinacie:
Her want of complaiſance for my Amours
Is th' only reaſon why I haunt her now:
Not that I value her perſon, but I take
A pleaſure in diſpleaſing her; nor but
By vexing her can I wipe off the ſhame
This ſeeming Conſtancy would blaſt me with.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: What a wrong ſenſe I took you in all this while?

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Why, you love her not then?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Not I, I thank my Starrs.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Why do you viſit her then? why write? why ſend?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: What in the name of Madneſs maketh you
That you are not in Love, play the fool, as thoſe do that are?

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Peeviſhneſs, I tell thee, meer peeviſhneſs;
Had ſhe, when firſt I courted her,
With leſs ſeverity welcom'd my Affection,
The fit had ſoon been over;
And in my way of making love, to another
E're this I had made offer of my heart;
But to knit one's brow, and look wiſe ſo out of ſeaſon,
To fume and fret at every merry word,
And pay with frowns inſtead of ſmiles
A whole day together;
Then do I make love in deſpight.

sp.speaker: Bern
sp.l: Marry, y'are a terrible Lover indeed!

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: I ſee 'tis dangerous for a Woman to have to do with you; why? would you have 'em love you whether they can or no?

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Is it ſo unpard'nable a Crime not to make much of you, that the puniſhment muſt never have end?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: But when will your Inconſtance-ſhip get a new Miſtriſs, and think of this no more?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: As ſoon as thy dexterity has ſifted out
VVho I am ſlighted for?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Why, for Bellamy perhaps

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: For Bellamy?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Yes, for that very Bellamy
That has Courted her, you know, theſe Twelve Moneths
D'ee laugh?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: That were a fine Match indeed!
Of all the gay men that frequent her
I ne'r was jealous of him yet.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Why, he's a proper Gentleman, though but a poor one.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Clarinda is too proud to look ſo low
A mind like hers on ſtate and bravery ſett,
Is with a Fortune not a Perſon taken;
This Bellamy too has ever been her ſcorn.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: What, if that were but a trick?
A meer diſſembling trick, to couſen the old Man?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: They have more tricks then one then; for Bellamy
A week ſince left the Town;
Nay's ſhipt for France e'r this,
And yet you'd have 'em ſmitten ſtill.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: There may be a trick in the Journey too, for—

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Peace, yonder's Beatrix, feel her pulſe a little,
Enquire, enquire how matters go; we'l ſtep aſide.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: 'Tis enough, I have my kue.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Let's give him opportunity.—

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: What art thou thinking of now?
sp.stage: In a melancholly poſture, his Cloak about his face.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Who I? I'm thinking of nothing.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: What? in your dumps, when I come? when your Love comes?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: My Love? I have no Love, not I;
My Maſter loves no more, and I love no more neither.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: In earneſt, Shift?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Yes in good earneſt, Beatrix.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: What, wilt thou forſake me now?
Thou canſt not be ſo hard hearted ſure?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: But I can, and will.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: This is but to try the conſtitution of my heart,
And peradventure to morrow.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Nay, there is no peradventure, nor no to morrow;
Is it not always like Maſter, like Man?
Make thy Miſtriſs love him, and then—

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Thou muſt not requeſt impoſſibilities at my hands,
Likely things I would do.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Why? is Clarinda ſuch a Love-hater?—
Is ſhe ſo inflexible?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Not ſo much; but—

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: But? but what?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: My poor Shift, thou haſt ſo often promis'd me.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Let us come to the But; go on with your ſtorie.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: What ſhould I tell thee?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Why Clarinda uſes Endimion with ſuch baſe neglect?
And whether or no to love her ſtill
Be operam & oleum perdere?
Thou maiſt ſmell my meaning, for Lamp-oyl has a ſtrong ſent.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: I could tell thee all this and more; but—

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: But what again?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: I'm forbidden.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: I'm glad o'that; ſhe'l tell therefore.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Yet if thou wouldſt ſwear not to tell again—

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Why I can be as ſilent as the ſilent woman;
I'le be a dumb ſhew; or the Chorus to't at leaſt,
I'le tell but all I ſee: judge by my taciturn aſpect.
I never tell but one thing at a time.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Thou wilt not tell then?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Not I; what I do not know.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: But ſwear to keep counſel.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: By my ſhifting faith, I will. Is not that well ſworn?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Shifting faith? heyday! what faith's that?
This is an oath of a new fabrick ſure,
What anvil came it off? prythee did'ſt thou forge it?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: The faith of Shift is a ſhifting faith:
But let not that ſtick with thee;
Men ſhift their faith now-a-days, as often
As they did their Trenchers, when this old Cap was new.
But to the point.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: You muſt know then that Clarinda, my Miſtreſs—
But you muſt not tell your Maſter, Shift.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: You would fain ſhift by your ſtorie,
sp.p: But 'twill not be: let me have it then, and quickly; for now I obſerve you better, I find by your ſimpring, and by the fumbling of your apron (that's a main ſign) that if I long to hear it, thou doſt e'en twitter to tell; leave your halting then before as very a Cripple as your ſelf, and come roundly to the buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Why, I muſt tell thee then—

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: No Prefaces, nor Preambles.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: That if thy Maſter be unkindly dealt with,
The reaſon is Clarinda

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Has another Love.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Th'art e'en i'th right on▪t.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Well, his name, his name? go on.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Muſt you know more yet?
Y'are very inquiſitive into Women's matters.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: I do not talk like a man-midwife? do I?
His name, I ſay, his name?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Bellamy.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: That poor Cavalier?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: 'Tis a noble compleat Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: And with his compleat Gentility
Thy Miſtreſs will ſend thee to market? yes, ſhe may;
But then muſt thou pawn thy coif and pinner,
Or come home without Eggs and Butter.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: She dot's on him, who can help it?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: All the dotage is on her ſide belike,
Hee'd nere leave her ſure to go for France,
Did he dote too.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: That Journey on deſign is given out;
But to ſpeak truth, ſhould he fall into the free-booters hands
We were in ſome danger.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: He's ſafe then, and on this ſide the ſea?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Yea, and in London too, as I may tell you.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: In London?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: And nere was out on't.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Who the devil taught him to Romance ſo finely?
To delude all the town, but Clarinda,
And you their confiding Mopſe,
He has taken as ſolemn a leave
As he had been going to Tangler, or to Tyburn.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: By this means he ſees Clarinda every night, by her appointment too, and has done this week: and while his friends pity him, and think him ſea-ſick, he's Land-ſick, and Love-ſick, good Gentleman. There's but ſmall hopes, thou ſee ſt, for thy Maſter.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: So me thinks.
But is not your Ladie afraid of the Lampon-makers?
Has ſhe a mind to be in a Ballad?
There are ſome Women have had whole bundles made of'em
Upon leſs occaſion, (as they ſay themſelves.)
Hoard up ſmooth faces, keep 'em leiger in a garret all day
To play at bopeep by night.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Alas! thou art too ſevere, to young Ladies eſpecially;
The nights the onely time for their recreation:
But we have a care of our ways,
And make a Conſcience of being taken in 'em,
I'd have you know.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Juſt as the Lacedemonians did of pilfering.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Why 'tis not a blot till it be hit, Man.
This night-work is ſo contriv'd.
That Bellamy ſteals into the garden by a back-door,
Which I leave open for him, and ſo to an arbour,
Where ſhe waits his coming.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: An excellent Rendez-vous for a midſummer Moon,
But this hot weather won't laſt always.
Where ſhelters he all day?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: At Gratian'S, as cloſe as he that fears an Execution,
And that's the reaſon too perhaps he gives his friend
Of this concealment, for he's not of the Councel,
Nor ſhould I have been, I think;
Could they have carried buſineſſes without me:
But I am right neceſſary Woman ſometimes.
Fare thee well, give me thy hand;

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Farewel, farewel.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Thou doſt promiſe me, Shift?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Promiſe thee? what?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Marriage, and't ſhall pleaſe thee.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Go thy ways, I do; when we are at age.
Is this the honour they vapour with?
This the reputation they are ſo ſhie of?
How many are there of this deceitful ſex,
That wear Vertue enough all day,
And lay it by at night with their black patche;
And the reſt of their ſuperfluous ornaments?
Has Clarinda her Love-qualms too? well, the
Beſt of 'em have their failings, that I ſee.
But now am I as over-loaden with this ſecret;
Oh, how heavie it is? I ſhall ſhrink under the burthen
An I carrie it any further; I'm ſure I'm ſick on't alreadie.
O here's my Maſter, he'l cure me.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Haſt thou found out the reaſon of my diſgrace?
Is Clarinda engag'd elſe-where?
Is it pride, is it hate makes her ſo coy?
What other Gallants has ſhe? why doſt not ſpeak?
Art deaf? or haſt thou loſt thy tongue?

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Why ſtandſt thou making faces thus, and clutching thy fiſt?

sp.speaker: End
sp.l: Why doeſt thou ſqueeze thy fingers ſo? ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: O good Sir, let me alone.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Let thee alone? why what art doing?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: You'l put me out now;

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Put thee out? of what? th' art out of thy wits already ſure.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Now was I ſtriving all this while to hold my peace;
I was bid; but the truth is, I am ſo farre
From doing as I was bid,
That I'm e'en weary of ſtriving already: heark you then
That Spruce, Compleat out-ſided Gallant, he that of all
Her gay frequenters nere gave you Jealous pang,
That very Bellamy, I told you of before,
That gives out he's gone for France,
By Clarinda's own contrivance is conceal'd at Gratian's.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Bellamy in town ſtill?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: As ſure as you are; and ſee's her every night.
Alas, he had no arrant into France,
But to make an aſs of your Worſhip,
And that it ſeems he can do better at home.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: One of 'em ſhall dearly pay for't though.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Why, what d'you mean to do?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Nay, I'm reſolv'd, I'le to Clarinda again.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Oh poor Beatrix, you'll tell Sir now,
And then is ſhe undone for ever.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: No, no, ne'r fear it.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: What good will it do you to ſee her then?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I mean to laugh at her, and for a full revenge
With deep proteſts will I renew my ſuit
If ſlighted, i'th ſame coin I'll pay her inſtantly,
And give her ſcorn for ſcorn;
A biting jeaſt or two, and I am even with her.
When ſhe peceives my Vows were raileries,
Which meerly to divert my ſelf I paſs'd upon her,
'T will ſhrewdly pinch her, that I'm ſure of,
For ſhe that thinks ſhe's fair indeed,
VVill ne'r endure to have been told ſo but in jeſt.
But prethee the whole ſtory of this fine Amouretta,
Bellamy ſees her every night, it ſeems.
I cannot wiſh 'em joy yet heartily,
There are ſome dregs of Love ſtill lurking under my anger.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Lewis ſir is here. End. 'tis well.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: You ſhall know more anon.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Go thou, and warily ſift out
Of ſome Neighbour or ſo, if I may ſee Clarinda.
That is whether—

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: I underſtand, you are afraid of the old Man,
You would have him ſafe.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: ſmiling. Th' art i' th' right
That's a ſtumbling block muſt be remov'd.

sp.speaker: Lewis.
sp.l: May a friend be partaker of your Mirth?
Or know but whence it ſprings?
Clarinda without doubt
Has better thoughts of Love then ſhe was wont,
'Tis not an unbecomming weakneſs now, I hope,
Y' have wrought a cure upon her, I ſee it in your looks.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Nothing leſs; ſhe never was more avers'd, nor I
More loſt to all hopes of ever being favour'd by her.

sp.speaker: Lewis.
sp.l: In what tearms then muſt one condole your loſs?
Or with what Arguments.—

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Nay, never ſet your Rhetorick o' th' Tenterhooks for the matter,
Not quicken your invention with your nails,
He can live without her.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I praiſe my manly temper.
The loſs Lewis I do not much regret;
And wert thou fit for ſuch a ſecret now—

sp.speaker: Lewis.
sp.l: You do me wrong to doubt my keeping it.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I would acquaint thee with my whole Adventure:
I have diſcover'd how the Market goes,
And ſee why I am not thought to bid fair,
The ſcorns Clarinda heapt on me
Were favours ſhe oblig'd a Rival with;
She's in love man, deſperately in love
See how the World's miſtaken in her,
And how groundleſs my pretenſions are.

sp.speaker: Lewis.
sp.l: Clarinda in love? vers'd with that ſubtilty too
In his diſſembling Maxims to carry it thus?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Nay, 'tis a wonder; ſhe that ſtood upon her guard
And kept us at ſuch diſtance, to be taken?

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: She that ſet Love and Lovers at defiance,
And ſeem'd ſo ſcrupulouſly modeſt, that to name
I ut Venus to her or Cupid, was talking bawdy.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: But who's the luckie Woodman has ſtruck this fair Doe?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: That's the wonder of all wonders, Bellamy.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Away, away, now I ſee you jeſt.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: It is a ſerious and a ſober Truth, ſir,
A ſad one too it might prove for ſome body,
Had not I more diſcretion then all Lovers have.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: The French journey's but a fiction, Man,
A meer ſlight to make their meetings
Private and unſuſpected.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: But ſee what a goodly choice ſhe has made,
What a happineſs ſhe refuſes me for;
A Man of no Fortune, Eſtate I mean,
For luck he has enough to fool me;
If 'twere wit he out-did me at,
He'd do't above board, and by day-light.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Y'are miſinform'd, I'm ſure on't;
I know Clarinda better then ſo, beſides Bellamy
For another Beauty burns, though't flame not out.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: For who?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: For Celia.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Have you acquaintance with her?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Not much; this I know, ſhe's a great Gallant,
L • ves in the Fields here, with a Widow-Aunt
And is Courted by him; 'tis true, Gratitude
As much perhaps as Love, may draw that Courtſhip
For his engagements to the Lady are great,
His boſome friend has told me all,
One that were happy could your ſurmize prove true.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I go upon ſure grounds, Beatrix is my Author,
And not to tell you a ſecret by the halfes
He keeps cloſe at a friends houſe of yours all day,
At Gratian's-

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: See where he comes; give me leave, and Ile know all;
He'l make no ſecret of't to me, I'm confident,
Nor will I to you of what I learn from him.
What penſive ſtill?

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: And miſerable ſtill.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: What new misfortune cauſes this complaint?

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: 'Tis an old grief mine, Lewis; how often
Have I told you with what paſſion
I burn for Celia, and with what violence
Done to my ſelf I do forbear all words
That might diſcloſe that paſſion a friend
Is Rival in? judge of my miſerie then,
For ſure no torments equallize his pain,
That dyes for love, yet dares not once complain.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: How out of ſeaſon theſe reſpects are now?
When Bellamy's abſence gives you place;
Take th' opportunity,

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: I'm ne're the happier for a Rivals abſence.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: No? that's ſtrange; but I hear, let me tell you,
His French Journey's laid aſide, nay, was ne're intended.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Who tells you ſo?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Nay more, 'tis whiſper'd he lies private at your houſe,
Nere ſeem amaz'd, but deal ingenuouſly.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: I did not think it had been known abroad.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Not is it generally; but what is his deſign?
Or what can he aim at by this ſtealth?

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: I never div'd ſo farr into his breaſt:
I onely underſtood it did concern his life,
Or what was dearer then his life, his Love,
To diſappear ſome time:
All I can gueſs beſides, (and that
But by ſome words he does drop forth by chance)
Is, that ſome jealous thoughts diſturb his mind,
And that to trie his Celia's real kindneſs,
He ſpreads this fain'd report of travel,
That as his abſence proves to this fair one
Irkſom or indifferent,
He may ſee the power of Rivalling Pretenſions.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: 'Tis hotly rumour'd though he loves Clarinda.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: That's the town-trick:
Becauſe he's young and courtly, Clarinda handſom,
He cannot viſit her, but ſtraight
He's thought in love; nay, though ſhe be not
Beyond common Civility regarded by him,
Yet People need's will have him her Adorer.
The news with Celia too has wrought ſo farre,
'Thas coſt her tears; but he in ſuch perſuaſive terms
Still vindicates his conſtancie,
She cannot long believe him falſe.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Is ſhe ſo much his then ſtill?

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Too faithful to him ever, too fond indeed:
Though without taking leave he ſtole away,
She ſeeks her ſelf pretences to excuſe him,
And with ſuch care does palliate his neglects,
As ſtops my mouth, and fruſtrates all my hopes.
While I (and that's my height of miſerie)
To make him happy, court my own ruine,
Viſit her at his requeſt, wooe her for him,
And improve each minute to diſcourſe his Love,
Fanning their heats thus, and childiſhly
Playing in a flame that muſt conſume me.
She, with the very name of Bellamy raviſht,
To ſit and chat of him intreats my viſits:
I muſt comply.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: 'Tis ſomething a ſevere compliance.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Thus keep I ſtill ſome intereſt in the family,
And have acceſs to her; and if by ſome
Capriciouſneſs of fate, which oft breaks kindeſt leagues,
They chance to jarre, ſhe may perhaps reflect
A faithful friend ſeldom proves faithleſs Lover.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: I wiſh it may be ſo.
But you'ld be viſiting this cruel fair one.
May ſhe with juſtice ballance both your ſervices,
And then yours will be crown'd.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: See where ſhe comes the fair Cauſe of all my grief;
No more then let the fear of diſpleaſing her keep it in,
For though I ſhould fall under her diſdain,
Her beauty is concern'd I make it known
Her eyes have captiv'd her more ſlaves then one:

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: How happily do I meet you?
Sure Bellamy is landed long ere this?
A letter from Callis now me thinks, to make his peace.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Madam, I expect ſome by the French poſt.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Why writ he not from Dover? nay,
From Canterbury, from Rocheſter, from Graves-end?
Are they not all poſt-towns?
Oh! I could have found twenty ways to ſend to him.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: How well my Cozen knows the road?
Yet I dare ſwear ſhe ne're was further
That way, then Southwark-fair.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Oh this Love is a ſubtle teacher, Mris Fannie.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Has it taught you any thing, Luce?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Nay, I have reaſon to be angry with him,
To ſteal away thus, and never bid adieu.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Thence you may judge how great his paſſion is,
That fatal word, Adieu, had he but ſpoke it,
Muſt have been his laſt; of ſo much beauty,
So much kindneſs too, who without dying
Could have taken leave?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I'm eaſily won, Gratian,
To a favourable conſtruction of all he does;
My love indeed pleads for him ſtill: and yet
What ere the reaſon of his abſence be,
I might, me thinks, have been acquainted with it.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Nay, Madam, I excuſe him not, he is too guilty;
I know what courteſies he is indebted to you,
With what a liberal hand you ever pour'd them on him,
And that when—

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: No more of that, I pray;
A Courteſie looſes its merit if publiſht once;
Would I be minded oft, I did deſerve
He ſhould forget it. Beſides if I may
Freely own the motive of thoſe actions
I pleaſur'd my ſelf moſt in obliging him,
I did but juſtice to his fair deſert:
And yet I'le not acquit him neither, I'le think
As you would have me more deſervingly
Of what I did; there's no gift though he's bound
To me for, ſaving that of my heart, my
Love I'ld have requited, then all is paid.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: That is the gift too he does value moſt:
And that he might not all Ungrateful ſeem
To the fair giver, when a neceſſity
Sudden as unwelcome forc'd him from what he lov'd,
He ſought to leave you one half of himſelf
Gratian, to fill his room.
And friendſhip now making but one of us,
If 'mong your diſcontents you reckon his abſence,
It ſhall be my care to ſupply his place;
With tears and ſighs I'le figure you his grief,
And will (to act your Bellamy to th' life,)
Forget I am not he; from the ſame Eyes
I'le draw my warmth, with the ſame paſſions burn,
And in this perſonated Love outvie—

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Enough, enough: for I begin to fear
Leaſt the pretence of ſpeaking for another
Should urge you further then a friends intereſt
Uſually does, friendſhip tranſports you, Gratian;
Temper its heat a little.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: A forward Proxie! hee'ld wed, and bed her
For his friend, would ſhe but let him.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: But ſhee's not ſo comming; though he
Would fain take himſelf for Bellamy,
She'll not miſtake him ſo too.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: My ſilence argued me remiſs and ſlack,
And venture at a word, I'm beaten back.

div.head: ACT. II.
The SCENE, Lincolns-Inn-fields.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: BY my modeſty, Madam, I'le keep your Counſel: Alas
I ſtand in need of the like good office my ſelf ſometimes,
And they that tell deſerve to be told of, I ſay.
Yet could I but underſtand what you drive at
I might be more ſerviceable.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: What account can I give thee?
In ſuch perplexitie my mind's involv'd,
I know not what I would my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: You love Bellamy though,

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Oh Wench I do.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: And that's it puzzles me now, to ſee ſo high an affection
Muſhrom-like ſprung up o'th ſudden, Bellamy
Has courted you, and recourted you ſigh'd & ſob'd, again & again,
Yet all would not do, you were as coy ſtill and as calm,
As nothing had been; nothing but frumps
Could he get of you in a whole years time,
Nothing but No's, and I wo' not's, and I cannot's,
And now in one week y'are ſo ſtrangely alter'd,
As you were turn'd the wrongſide outward;
Y'are got into the loving extream now.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Alas! I lov'd him all that while;
Though knowing how much a Wealthy fathers bent
Againſt Pretenders of ſo ſmall a fortune,
Set cold neglect and rigour in my eyes,
While my heart e'en melted with hot love.
This ſeeming cruelty had driven him into France,
Could I have worn it ſtill, but thou ſaw'ſt me
Beaten from that ward; and yield, though he
Gave out he went, he ſhould not go indeed.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Truly y'are to be pitied: but what good
Can this counterfeiting of a Journey do you?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: His intentions for travel were too well known abroad,
To have the Journey broken thus o'th ſudden;
And ſifting out the cauſe, perhaps
Something o'th' truth of it might have been found.
'Tis ſafer to keep cloſe by day awhile,
And then pretend ſome reaſon for's return.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Endimion, Madam.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: His importunity will nere have end.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Is it not juſt I quarrel with my Starrs
That I can never ſee you? will you keep home always?
Muſt none enjoy you, but your ſelf?
I ſhall grow jealous of yourſelf at laſt.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Home is moſt pleaſing to me, and retired thus
I ſee but what I like, and will my ſelf;
What moves you to preſs on my retirement?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Will you never take pity of my ſufferings?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Bewail your ſelf ſome where elſe, I'm ignorant of your griefs.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Love.—Clar. Never name a Tyrant I abhor.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: But a Lover that ſuffers.—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Leave out that name of Lover,
There is ſuch a diſcord in the ſound, I hate it.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Unjuſtly though, methinks;
For ſure with fewer charms Nature does frame
What ſhe means not the object of our Loves.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Will you never leave this odious talk?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Will you be lovely thus, and cruel ſtill?
Oh what Flames do thoſe Eyes kindle in my breaſt!

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: What averſion does this diſcourſe beget in mine!

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Heavens! how they ſparkle? how many deaths
They ſhoot, thoſe Star-like twins?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Oh, I could hate the Sun, whoſe light I ſee you by.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: The Moon indeed is ſomething kinder to you,
No doubt, but to her light
You are beholding for a lovelier ſight.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I underſtand you not.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: You will not.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: You think to fright me with this obſcure diſcourſe.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I can clear it, if I am put to't.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Nay, 'tis time to be gone then;
I ſee y'are angry, and might uſe me worſe,

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: ſtaying her Without hearing my reaſons?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I care not for 'em:

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: But you muſt hear 'em though; 'tis a Love-ſuit
I am concern'd in, you ſhall be judge i' th' caſe;
Y'have heard my Adverſary at leiſure,
And tane perhaps ſome prejudice againſt my right;
'Tis my turn now to have an Audience of you,
Since he has it by night, I may well
Claim one by day; not that I do expect
A Garden door ſhould be left jarr'd
For me to ſlip in, nor Beatrix there
Confidingly to watch, none interrupt my ſtory;
Much leſs that you your ſelf ſhould wait
My comming in an Arbour.
Were I ſuppos'd in France, and yet in ſpight of Seas
Could meet you at an hours warning, then indeed
I might deſerve a kin ••• welcome.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: A pox on's memory! he has not left out a tittle,
What a ſpeech has he made here?
Could I find no body elſe to tattle too?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: What have I heard?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Oh Sir! what have you done?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: 'Tis but a juſt revenge of her unjuſt
And undeſerved ſcorn.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: to Be. Thou haſt betrayed me,

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Believe me, Madam.—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Away thou faithleſs wretch, thou haſt ſold me;
Unhappy ſhe, that truſts ſuch mercenary ſouls.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: to End. Now will poor Beatrix be turn'd away.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: I would to Heaven you did not with your anger
Avow your ſelf what I had ſtill conceal'd,
And this reproaching me did not confirm.—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Peace Impudence: juſtifying yourſelf?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: to End. I had need of a good back now,
'Twill all fall upon me.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: 'Tis paſt now, who can help it? but for my intereſt,
For thine own, for Beatrix ſake, for all; prethee Shift
And thou canſt, peece it up again; make any ſhift.
Invent, Frame, Lye, Swear, anything, I'le ſecond it.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Nay, 'tis reſolv'd, ne'r ſpeak on't more:

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Well, I muſt pack then, ſince you'l have it ſo
But may I now before your face, if ever I told tale.—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Oh, 'tis an innocent piece!

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: I have much adoe ſir, to make a good lie o'th' ſudden;
But this ſhall ſerve for want of a better.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Good or bad, let's have it; I'le help thee out.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: And you turn me away to morrow ſir, I will tell
I'le ſpeak the Truth in ſpight of all Maſters, I:

sp.speaker: To Clar.
sp.l: Madam, put up your anger, or turn it the right way:

sp.speaker: To End.
sp.l: Nay, never wink on me, nor frown,
Nor make me ſigns to hold my peace;
Truth muſt be heard, and ſhall.

sp.speaker: To Clar.
sp.l: Beatrix never betray'd your ſecrets,
Nor does ſhe prattle of your Love,
The Stars, the Stars themſelves diſcover'd all.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: What means the Fellow?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: You don't believe me now?
But I muſt tell you though, and you'l find it true too,
That this Maſter of mine (as out of countenance as you ſee him)
Has not ſtowage for his great Capacity,
Nor the World his fellow in Aſtrology,
The Man i' th' Strand was an Aſs to him, when he was at beſt,
He can make the Brazen head ſpeak at this hour,
Spirits he could raiſe Sans nombre
And make them talk too,
Till we were all weary of their company.
If ever an Endimion ſlept in the Moon's lap,
This is he, for he has as much familiarity with her,
To my knowledge, as that comes to.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Thy Maſter an Aſtrologer?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: I, Twenty.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: What Twenty Aſtrologers, and but one Man?
Thou wilt tell a lie anon.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: I mean, he caſts Figures, and raiſes Appearances
As faſt as Twenty;

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: This ſtory'll cry me up for a fine fellow.

sp.speaker: To Sh.
sp.l: What ſirrah? Sh. Yes ſir.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: If ſhe would but believe him now!

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Nay, you are an Aſtrologer if ever man was:
I know I looſe my place, and forfeit my no ſmall
Arrears of wages too in diſcovering it,
But I love Beatrix, Queen of Beatrixes.
And ought to free her from the ſuſpicion

sp.speaker: To Clar.
sp.l: Her Miſtreſs has conceiv'd; he has made me mad
This week with his Ovals and his Circles,
He contemplates the Stars in nights ſo dark
They dare not appear, and is ſtaring abroad,
When the dogs will not peep out.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Well ſaid, Bull-dog!

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: By Moon-light, by Owl-light, by any light,
By no light; and in his Chamber
Continually poaring on a great black Book
Full of pot-hooks of all ſorts and ſizes,
The Inventory o' th' Devils Kitchin, 'tis I think:
And thus has he diſcover'd your Amours
But in what Devils name, or which leaf of the Book
Y'are written in, truly that I cannot tell you yet.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: This is a jeſting Knave, and yet
There may be ſome Truth in what he ſays too;
Stranger things have been found out by that Art.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Why, thou everlaſting prittle prattle!
Will't never have done? who has hired thee here
To tell a ſtory of a Cock and a Bull?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: I▪ I, Cocks and Bulls; thoſe are ſome of your Familiars.
Madam, I have not ſaid a word, but what is true.
I'le juſtify't, let him raiſe as many devils as he will,
What I have ſaid will ſhame 'em all.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Meaning, 'tis truth he has ſpoke;
Which is not the leaſt of his lies.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Did not you ſhew me a Garden.
Laſt night, in one of your enchanted Glaſſes,
And bid me mark an Arbour to the Weſt of that Garden?
I know not Weſt from Eaſt, not I;
But I perceiv'd it ſtood in one corner of the Garden,
And mark'd it ſo well, I can tell you
What 'twas made of too, of Lauretine.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: There is ſuch an Arbor i'th' Garden.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Yes Madam, there is indeed:
God-a-mercy though, that he ſaw it once,
When I took him into th' Garden,
His Maſter's glaſſes had nere ſhew'd it him elſe.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: But that you chiefly bade me obſerve,
And were your ſelf ſo vext at heart to ſee,
Was the Lady Clarinda here ſitting in that arbour;
In a melancholy poſture you were, I'le aſſure you, Madam,
Thus with your hand ſupporting of your head,
And look'd, in my eye, as you had waited
For ſomething, made you think the time long ere it came;
And ſo it prov'd indeed; for caſting by command my eye
To another ſide of the Mirrour, I ſpied a Gallant
Enter'd the Garden make ſtraight up to the arbour,
And ſaw your firſt ſalute; 'tis true, I could not
Hear him what he ſaid, (and by that I gueſs
The devil's not ſo great with th' ears as with the eyes.)
But I ſuppoſe he did excuſe his coming late,
And took ſuch ſpecial notice of his garbe,
I'd know him in a croud of Courtiers,
Amongſt clowns any one might diſcern him,
I could deſcribe his habit too for need—

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Oh! you have ſaid enough, Sir, you have ſaid enough;
And more then will ſtand with my credit, Madam,
To have believ'd, I'm worſe then an Aſtrologer then,
He makes me conjure too: but ſince it is not
For my honour now to hide the truth from you;
I muſt confeſs that in my travels
'Twas my fortune to grow intimate with a learned Man,
Sometime a Scholar to the fam'd Noſtredamus,
Who took ſome pains with me, my aptneſs
To his impreſſions making him with pleaſure, as he ſaid,
Impart his ſecrets, nor knew he ought
In Phyſiognomy, Palmiſtry, Aſtronomy,
Nor hardly in all the Mathematicks
He read not to me; what ere belongs, I'm ſure,
To th' Opticks or Mechanicks he did diſcloſe.
Thus came my skill.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: I never heard this ſo perfectly before.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: I don't think thou didſt.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: But to own it publickly
I know too well the diſrepute 'tis in
Amongſt the Vulgar, too apt to give events
(Whoſe cauſe their dull capacity cannot reach)
To the black Art, and think the devil author
Of all ſubtleties above 'em; which makes my man
Talk of familiars, and take (dull brain!)
Our Optick glaſſes for enchanted one's.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Beſides the wrong ſome late Profeſſors too
Have done that art, by proſtituting it
To men in power.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: A ſervile flatterie!

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Made him more cautious in ſuch times as thoſe,
When it was dangerous not to be baſe,
How he ſeem'd knowing.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: But tired out at laſt with
Your too rigorous uſage, your ſervants all
Too truſty, or too ignorant to betray me
The cauſe on't;
I was reſolv'd to find it out my ſelf
In that great book, where truth's ſo fairly writ
For thoſe have ſtudied the bright Character:
I did conſult the ſtars,
I found the garden, and the arbour too,
Bellamy's real happineſs, and ſuppos'd abſence.
But let not this diſcovery trouble you,
For my own intereſt I muſt keep your Counſel,
Our fortune is the ſame, 'tis but one ſecret for another,
My Man has told you mine, I found out yours,
Keep you but one of 'em, and I warrant you for the other.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: 'Tis an able Man, I promiſe you!

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: You'l believe me another time, I hope,
I was i'th right, you ſee.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: The truth, I trow, does juſtifie me now, Madam.
I had heard it mutter'd indeed, he took upon him
To tell fortunes, interpret dreams, or ſo;
And could have made Almanacks too, for his skill,
But that he thought it a diſcredit to his youth,
To grow weather-wiſe ſo ſoon: but I had ſold you,
I had betrayed you, I; he knew all from me.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Truth, I was loath to ſuſpect thee,
I had no former grounds for't;
Had it not been for his Aſtrologie though,
What could he have known, unleſs I had been betray'd.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: You may, remember too, if any Incredulity remain,
How much my old Maſter talks of Aſtrologie,
And what feats he was wont to do in's youth,
As he tells us, by the Vertue of Mars and Venus.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: My father talks much of Aſtrologie indeed,
What I have heard from him, helps to perſwade,

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Thou could'ſt not pitch upon a quainter fancie.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Twas extempore, Sir, remember that,
And may give ſome ſmall hint of my faculty;
A little premeditation had afforded you a better.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: It needs not, this fable is as currant with her.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Nay, ſhe is finely fool'd; you ſhall
Have her in ſuch a ſuppliant Style now,
She's ſore afraid of you, I ſee by her eyes.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Noble Endymion, whoſe clear-ſighted mind
Is onely paralel to your generous heart.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Did I not tell you?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Hear her Apologie.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: A ſlighted Lover's anger I ſhould fear,
Were the excuſe I am now to make you,
Due to any other, but you that know
The Influence of the ſtars, and force of deſtiny,
Will not deem it a Crime in me, to act
What they decree: when great ones can't eſchew
What they portend her, what ſhould weak women do?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Peace, peace, your father's coming,
Your father's coming; 'tis his hem.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Would he would hem ſome where elſe,
We did not want him here.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Now, what's the buſineſs with this young Gallant?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: 'Tis Curioſity, Sir, I muſt confeſs;
I heard not long ſince by a friend of mine,
He was moſt knowing in Aſtrologie,
And having by her means wrought his acquaintance,
A Maiden-longing, which I bluſh to own,
Made me now queſtion him 'bout my husband's name,
And when I ſhould be married.
I'le try your skill though for once good Mr Aſtrologer.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: The old man wil have him into the Star-chamber preſently.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: She doubts my ſcience, & ſets him on to make trial of't to Sh.
I le bear up bravely, and 't ſhall go hard,
But I'le beat that old tired Cock out o'th' pit.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Are you a fortune-teller? do'e make Almanacks? hah!

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Montelions perhaps, or ſo.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: He's the ſpruceſt truly o'th trade, I ere yet ſaw.

div.stage: They ſtand aſide with Shift, who tells them what has paſt between his Maſter and Clarinda.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: How rudely the man begins? this is no fair diſputant.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: What does he tell thee troubles thee thus?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I told her, Sir, of ſome hard fortune, which
By th' malign aſpect of an inauſpicious Planet
I find her threatned with.
She takes it ſomewhat to heart, as you ſee.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Thou art too blame, thou art too blame
To be ſo much concern'd.
In ſo ſhort a time what could you diſcover?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: That ſhee's decree'd
To make the fortunes of a younger Brother,
Or ſome ſuch wanting Gentleman;
For he whom ſhe's to marrie
Is rich in perſon onely, and a comely mine.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Who would not think he ſpoke truth now,
He delivers himſelf with ſuch confidence?
The good Gentleman out-lies his man,
Foils him at his own weapon, Impudence.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Fear it not upon ſuch ſlight grounds,
'Tis but one Doctors, opinion, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I would I had not heard it though;
The Prediction has made ſtrong impreſſions on me.
Would it did ſo on you too, that you might be perſwaded
There were no remedy, but I muſt have Bellamy,
The fine wanting Gentleman he points at.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr
sp.l: My Daughter meat for younger Brothers?
Fear 'em not I ſay again, let me alone
To ſtave them off, and wanting Heirs are as bad to me
As a poor Cadet, I'le beware of them too.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Endimion, though that reads my deſtiny thus,
Is a knowing Man, Father, one never yet miſtaken,
Nor ever ſaw he, as he proteſts
The Stars on any one Event ſix'd ſo unanimous;
This would work, I think, on any one,
It falling ſo right with my own deſires.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: She takes more pains to delude her Father,
Then I did to gull her: I ſhall be an Aſtrologer
At this rate, whether I will or no.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Many Men have employ'd all their Lives
In this Study, and yet died ſhort
O' th' excellence of it too; and how this Man
Should arrive at the height of it ſo young,
I wonder much, I promiſe you.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: It is with Schollars, I have heard, Sir,
As with Travellers; not always he that firſt ſets forth,
But he that takes the neareſt way, gets ſooneſt home.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: And what of him that's beſt hors'd?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: He out-rides his fellows.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Why, thou art a parcel wiſe Man too.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Certes Aſtrologie is a noble Science,
Worth th' application of ingenious minds!
If you are ſuch a Maſter of her ſecrets,
Few that pretend to th' name come near
Deſerving it ſo well; all men
Are not fit for ſpeculation now a-dayes,
Youth eſpecially, is all on Action bent;
So young therefore, and ſo learned, deſerves
All Honour and Applauſe; and I am heartily yours.
I ever was affected to Men of merit,
A lover of Learning always, I:
And to ſpeak truth, in my younger days
I was a dabler this way too, my ſelf;
But marrying too ſoon, marr'd my Study,
My Wife burnt all my Books, and I ſoon fell
From caſting Figures, to caſt up accounts;
Domeſtick care, Law-ſuits,

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: And good-fellowſhip too a little.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Kept me from excelling▪ but tell me Sir, I pray;
Are not thoſe Planets (Mars and Saturn excepted)
Of the happieſt influence, whoſe Paralels are the greateſt?
How like you Mercury beholding Venus,
With a trine Aſpect? or, what think you,
Of the ſame Mercury in conjunction with Hecate?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: The Man ſpeaks Hebrew ſure;
And he would take his anſwer in Gibberiſh now,
'Twere ſome thing:

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Here are words as able to fright away an Ague,
As Voiture's Abracadabra

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: He had need be an Aſtrologer now indeed

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I'le have one puſh for't.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Heark, he has provided an anſwer

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: to Sr Chr. Thoſe Planets I account the happieſt, none excepted,
Whoſe influence on Man and Woman pour down
What each deſireth moſt.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Learnedly anſwered!

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Venus, you know your ſelf, (but that y'are pleas'd
To try my younger skill;) to Lovers does preſage all bliſs,
As Mars has a kindneſs for the Men of War;
Saturn is powerful with the Saturnians:
Marry, if Mercury eye Venus once,
There are Cuckolds made i'th' City:
Some falſe Dice▪ may be abroad too,
For he was a wag both ways, you know.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: But what if with a trine Aſpect, what then, Sir?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: That's worſt of all, Sir; then are the Cuckold-makers at work
In City, Court, and Countrey: if with a trine Aſpect,
Then let all Men look to their Wives,
Their handſome Wives eſpecially.
Oh, 'tis a Cornuting Conſtellation!

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: And governs this Cornuting age.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: I never heard why we had ſo many Cuckolds before.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Indeed, indeed, law-Daughter, I would
He had told thee thou ſhould'ſt have
A rich old Knight, or ſome Alderman;
For ſure enough he had reaſon for what he ſaid,

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: No queſtion but he had, though neither ſhe,
Nor you, know what reaſon

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: But what of the Conjunction, Sir,

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Of Mercury with Hecate?
I have much adoe to ſpeak the Goblin-words after him,
It is a very critical one.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Is it ſo? is it ſo? indeed?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Have at him now with down right non-ſence.
To Sr Chr. The Triplicity of it, as well as the Union
Of Hecate with Mercury, being Retrograde,
Or in combin'd Aſpects, in the Horizon
Of a croſs Aſcendant, on ſuch weak brains
Might paralax at laſt.—

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Y'are too high for me, I promiſe you;
This is all out of my reach; if you would deſcend
To ſomewhat a more vulgar and intelligible phraſe.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Theſe are terms of Art, Sir.
I thought I ſhould poſe you.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Pardon my age, Sir; 'tis ſo long ſince I
Broak Correſpondence with the Art, the tearms
Are as ſtrange to me now, as I ne'r had heard 'em;
And methinks too, they hardly were in uſe
When I was at the Univerſity:
But time that alters us, will alter Science too,
It has a daily increaſe, though we decay,
And other Countreys may have other Methods.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Of late years, Sir, in the Mathematicks
There are great alterations, they erect Schemes
A new way now, and have new names
Belonging to the Horoſcope, Noſtradamus him ſelf,
Whom my Maſter follow'd, had his tearms
And rules apart, wherefore the phraſe
I'm ſtudied in, may well ſeem ſtrange to you.
But School-men are like Carriers-horſes; We plod on
In our old pad; like us, or underſtand us, who will.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Do you ſo? do you ſo? That's ſomething ſtrange methinks,
Yet amongſt friends, you might vouchſafe, Sir, to be underſtood.

sp.speaker: La-gripe.
sp.l: To Sr Chr. A vord vis your Vorſhip.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: How now? what's the matter, Lagripe?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: You claw it away with hard words.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Thou ſeeſt, I ſweat for't;
But for a friend now at need, relieve me
With an errand, or find ſome trick or other
To take off this old Lover, of he knows not what

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Your Pardon, Sir, it is an earneſt buſineſs,
I ſhould not leave you elſe, I'm e'en full loath as, 'tis,
For I did long to underſtand thoſe new tearms,
That I did: but we ſhall meet again
And diſcourſe theſe learned Miſteries, we'l try
Some Mathematical experiments too;
Nay, I have ſome Secrets worth your knowing:
But farewel farewel for this time.

div.stage: Ex. Sir Chr. Clar. Beat. Lagripe.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I had rather believe you, then ſtand to ſift 'em out.
I'm rid of him without thy help at laſt.
Lewis, Bernard, I have had the fineſt adventure,
The prettieſt part put upon me.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Shift has made us laugh at it alreadie,

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: We ſtood aloof off all the while, and heard
How aſtrologically the old man queſtion'd you:

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: And as Aſtrologically I anſwer'd him, I hope:
But he could not follow through the houſes of the Sun
The pace I led him, he loſt ſight of me preſently.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: You did not vanquiſh him fairly, he underſtood you not.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: It had been much he ſhould,
When I did not underſtand my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: 'Tis fit you take ſome pains in both,
He'l expect an expounding viſit.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Bleſs me from undeſign'd Encounters,
Such as this day's; and if by my good will
I viſit him, let him plague me with non-ſenſe;
Let him retaliate, and ſpare not.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: D'ee mean to trade in non-ſenſe ſtill?
A great Aſtronomer, or one taken for ſuch—

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Hee'l quickly find how I played upon him,
For what queſtions did he put to a Man,
That knows neither Signs nor Planets?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: With your bold anſwers you ſo mall'd him though,
He's yet well ſtunnied, and with as much eaſe
I durſt wager, you'l foil him next encounter.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Give him t'other fall, compleat your Victorie,
'Tis for the credit of learning
The work be not left imperfect.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: We'l be the trumpet of your fame,
And ſound your skill throughout the town.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: What think you of poſting up bills?
As others of the profeſſion do.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: And give ſome at the Play-houſe doors
As they do for a match at the Bear-garden.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Or get him put into the Gazette
By way of Advertiſement for the publick good
Of what a Mine of Learning is diſcover'd.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Either will convince the old knight,
And if beſides, by ſtrangers we ſhall have prepar'd,
Th' amazing rumour of your daily wonders
But reach his ear, as I'le be ſure it ſhall;
Being full already of this firſt enterview,
He'l be ſo gull'd, as nere old dotard was.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: That I believe; but this fine paſtime
Venture's me a little too farre;
You conſider not the danger may enſue,
Engaging thus my credit, and my quiet too; for 'twill
Draw all the curious fools o'th' town about my ears.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: So we ſhall know how full the town is of fools,
And ſhould they find, y'are but a counterfeit,
'Twill paſs but for a trick of youth at worſt.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: What ſport ſoever we may fancie thus,
It cannot laſt long; for if it be
So generally bruited, I ſhall have queſti ns
Put me hourly, and then my anſwers.
Muſt doubtleſs get me great repute.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: What matter? you'l anſwer as other Pretenders do,
Sometimes I, ſometimes no; be it favourably,
Or fatally; have ſome reſpect to age and ſex,
And for the reſt, happy be lucky.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: A fortune-teller never warrants any thing;
You anſwer not upon oath, Sir; and then you know,
One may ſtrain a little, without venturing ears.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: In Aſtrologie the beſt of 'em does as much
By chance as skill: 'tis meer hab-nab.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: What if you throw Croſs or Pile, whether you ſay,
I, or no. or tell your buttons, I, no; I, no:

sp.speaker: End
sp.l: There are ways indeed.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Why, 'tis an even lay, you hit right either way,
When there is but a right and a wrong in the caſe.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Have I not read of a judge was ſwayed by
Caſt of Dice in trials of Life and death?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: The high fulloms ſav'd ſome, the low hang'd the reſt.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Right.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: This remember; never to affirm any thing
With certainty, with what is paſt or preſent
Be very cautious how you meddle,
'Tis as dangerous in this Profeſſion
As ſpeaking treaſon; o'th' future it ſelf
Speak but obſcurely neither, to your Conſulters
'Twill paſs for learnedly, they muſt
Allow you to be i'th' clouds a little.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Let your Anſwers be like Oracles, wonder'd at,
Not underſtood, foretel more good fortune
For the moſt part then bad,
That will ſend 'em away pleas'd at leaſt:

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: And in that good humour they'l remember
Your poor ſervants; our Wages may be earn'd this way.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Thou Mercenary fool.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Here's Gratian; be gone,
Wee'l begin with him, he's credulous.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I leave it t'ee, Gentlemen;
Manage the device as you will your ſelves,
Come Shift.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Who would have thought it?

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Who can well believe it yet?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: 'Tis ſtrange.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: 'Tis beyond imagination.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: How is it with you, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: We hardly know our ſelves;
We are wrapt in ſuch a cloud of Wonders;

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Moſt miraculous!

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: May not I know what? I would fain wonder too.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: I fear leaſt—

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: You need not; here's none to over-hear us.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: But it requires a ſecrecy.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Truſt me.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Endimion declar'd even now,

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Declar'd? what?

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: And did before our face things ſo incredible
Almoſt to eye-witneſſes, I'm loth to ſpeak 'em.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: What did he do?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: I never met with, nor indeed heard of his fellow.
He is ſo highly knowing in Aſtrologie,
And ſhews his skill in practiſes ſo admirable,
I could ſuſpect he conjur'd.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: He told me paſſages of my life, and almoſt in an inſtant,
Which without Enchantment, I know not
How he ſhould diſcover: yet all he did,
Was by Conjectures from my palm and face,
And certain figures drawn o'th' ſudden;
For he is alſo a Chiromancer, and a Phyſiognomiſt.
Who could imagine, ſeeing him ſo ſpruce, ſo gay?—

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Is it not Endimion the Wit, that travell'd Monſieur,
Whoſe Gallantry and Converſation are ſo much cried up:
He's of the Society too, I think.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Yes, yes, an eminent member: he has ſome rare ſecret ſure
Which other Artiſts are not yet arriv'd at.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: I ever took him for a well-willer
To the Mathematicks indeed; Some twice or thrice,
I think, I have convers'd with him,
And found him then, both by his Countenance and diſcours
An Aſtrologer, I will not ſay,
For that great knowledge he took care, belike,
To hide from all, but boſome friends;
But a perſon of ſharp wit and excellent underſtanding
I clearly ſaw he was;
A Man addicted too to curious ſciences.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: What will you ſay, if I carry you with me
Some day, that he has undertaken
To ſhew me a Beautie, had ſome kindneſs for me
In Paris? the French Miſtreſs y'have heard me ſpeak of.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Is't poſſible he can?—

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: That's nothing to what he can do.
He made a Picture ſpeak before us,
And that's the Cauſe of this aſtoniſhment.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: May I believe this?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: You have both Eyes an Ears, will you believe them?

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Dear Lewis, make me better acquainted
With this rare Man; he▪l tell me
Whether Bellamy be jealous, or no; and why.—

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: I have enquir'd that out for you already:
He meets Clarinda by night, and abuſes Celia.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: He does go out by night indeed

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: And to that purpoſe; never doubt it.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: I'm overjoy'd, if it be ſo.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: But not a word, dear Gratian, as you love me,
Of Endimion; he would be Lamm'd
If what we know were ſpread abroad.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Here's one i'th ſnare already.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Endymion an Aſtronomer, and Bellamy faithleſs!
Love give thee thanks, th' opportunity's a fair one;
I le ſtraight to Celia, there I'le boaſt his Art,
By which, (if Love and I can make her bold enough)
She may diſcover how ſhe is abus'd.
Then diſpoſſeſt
Of the fair thoughts ſhe holds of this falſe Man,
Her heart for me becomes an eaſie prize.
Nor can he tax me with a breach of truſt
That to his Miſtriſs is much more unjuſt,

div.head: The Firſt SCENE, Endimion's Lodgings.
div.stage: Enter Endimion, Lewis, Bernard, Rawman, Shift with a Satchel at his back.

sp.speaker: Lewis.
sp.l: FAmous Aſtronomer, moſt admired Genius,
You that are now the only Town-talk grown,
As never plot was half ſo well contriv'd,
So never any yet took as this does▪

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: No Man, but is perſwaded of your skill,
No Man, but with reſpect does gaze upon you;
And it ſome croſs accident ſpoil not the ſport,
You will be taken for a Prophet ſhortly.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: And to preſerve that good opinion, Sir,
See, I looſe no time.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Witneſs my burthen here.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Why, what haſt thou got there?

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: His Worſhips Library.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: I think I may be worthy to carry
Books after him, as famous a Man as he is.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: A Lillie's Almanack.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: And a Whartons.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: There's the Pro and Con
That will make him a good Diſputant.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Wings Ephemerides! I marry Sir,
Here's an Airy Author indeed.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: My Maſter ſoars as high as the loftieſt of 'em.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: You know the houſes of the Sun, I hope, by this.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: As well as any man here does Coffee-houſes or Bawdy-houſes.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Peace Scurrility; that he had houſes I knew before:

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: I ever held him a mighty Prince,
And did believe he was well lodg'd.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.p:
But now I know his Riſings and his Settings too, Heliack,
Coſmick, and Acronick; the number of the Spheres, both Tropicks, that of Cancer, and of Capricorn, the Artick and Antartick-Poles, the Paralels, Ecliptick-line, the Climate, Point-Vertical: and what not.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Nay then, I'le lay aſide this ſuperfluous Learning,
He has enough without book.

div.stage: Carrys in the Satchel and returns.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Alas Sir, Mercury in conjunction with Hecate.
Or beholding Venus with a trine Aſpect,
Thanks to my Almanack here, is not Hebtew now,
'Tis but a labour, though of memorie yet,
My Judgement is not much improv'd,
And I muſt ſhun Sir Chriſtopher a while;
But what progreſs have you made with the Pageant?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: A fair one, I think, for the time,

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Such as you'ld laugh to trace us thorow.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: My firſt ſtation was to a houſe where I
Was ſure I ſhould meet company, and of
The beſt; a kind of Lady-ordinary,
Where they were beaſting it, for that game's in
Faſhion ſtill, though Hombre be more Courtly.
To th' ſtanders by, I whisper'd firſt my news,
Then 'mongſt the Bettors it began to ſpread,
At laſt it wrought the Gameſters too, and found
Even amongſt the looſers ſuch concern,
They could ſit ſtill, and queſtion me about you;
They muſt play on though, but they were ſo full
of Signs and Planets, that in ſtead of Play
A Madam cried out Venus, and a Man
Of War for Counter, ſtraight cried Mars.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I fear 'twas I beaſted her.

sp.speaker: Lewis.
sp.l: When I ſaw t work ſo well, I left 'em, and to th' play;
Where to diſſeminate my ſtory beſt,
I'th' pit, I whiſper'd it from ear to ear;
And thus confidingly it ſpread ſo well,
That by the end it was in every mouth:
Going out, (I laugh ſtill at the conceit)
A friend rounds me i'th ear with my own lye,
Which with ſo many oaths he vouch'd for truth,
I made ſome ſcruple not to believe him.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: A moſt excellent progreſs!

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Is it not?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: But prethee Bernard, where haſt thou preacht me up?

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: To Court, I; for that's the ſtaple of news.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: I'le ſee what they ſay of my Maſter at the Bake-houſe,
For that's my ſtaple of news.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: But peeping by the way into th' Exchange,
I met with one did lye for you the heartilieſt,
Relating twenty monſtrous things y' had done,
To which he ſwore himſelf a witneſs too:
Some five or ſix had hemm'd him in,
And hung upon his tongue, his lying tongue,
With an attention great as his impudence;
I hearkened too a while, (then to try his mettle)
Took on me to conteſt ſome points he had averr'd:
But he, full fraught with wrath and indignation;
I ſpeak but what I' ve ſeen, and you perhaps
Gain-ſay't for want of knowledge of the perſon,
Or elſe you envie men of worth and parts.
When I, ſeeing him ſo fierce, for fear of being beaten,
E'en ſneak'd away to laugh at him at leiſure.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: What impudent fellows there are about this Town?
Travellers and Falk oners are modeſt to this vap'ring, Sir,
'Twere an excellent Genius to write Diurnals;
Is he not ſomething a kin to old Politicus, think you?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: He would out-lye him ſome furlongs

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Novelty has its Sectators every where
As groſs lies paſs for currant truth daily.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: They did indeed.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: But why baulk'd you Grays-Inn-walks, the Coffee-(houſes or ſome ſage Club.
There your grand News-mongers conferre.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Retailers of grave, ſerious lies, they:
But mine was for the young, the gameſome ones.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: And with what credit they receive it!

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Were I ſure, lying would always thrive thus,
I'ld make a vow never to ſpeak truth more.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: But at Court, Bernard.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: A Lady, Sir, a handſome Lady too,
though her hoods hide part of her beautie,
Would fain have you to her ſelf a while.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: To her ſelf? why, what would ſhe doe with me?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Was that a fit queſtion for me to ask?
As if they would tell ſervants,
What they do with their Maſters;
They are not ſo immodeſt, I hope.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Some of their ſtories would make me bluſh.
But this Lady looks with ſome honeſty,
And deſires to ſpeak with you in private.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Wait on her in.
Step you two into that drawing room a little.
If there were ſome Aſtrologie i'th' viſit now.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: I hope 'tis the Aſtrologer the Ladie makes it to.
You want ſuch Viſitants.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: You muſt wittily and boldly chiauſe two or three,
And then you'l be in Vogue indeed.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: What ere it be from hence you may obſerve us.

div.stage: Enter Celia, Fannie, Luce, Shift, Rawman.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Are you not ſurpriz'd at the confidence of ſuch a viſit?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I'm honour'd with it, Madam, beyond meaſure honour'd.
Beſhrew me 'tis a fair Lady indeed, a very fair one.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: I hope, Sir, I han't ſo little skill in beautie,
But you may take my word for a good face.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Truſt me, I do not ſee a better.
How may I ſerve you, Ladie? how may I deſerve
The pains y'have taken thus, to find me out?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: To ſee Endimion I would have done more;
With ſuch impatience did I long to be
Acquainted with the Genius of the age;
The learned'ſt Man our England ever bred.
Oh Luce! I tremble; I ſhall never have courage
To utter what I come about.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: What need you ſpeak at all? he can underſtand you
By ſigns and tokens, as well as he were deaf and dumb.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Madam, I want expreſſions to return
A Complement ſo ill-deſerv'd, 'tis true
I have ſome ſlight tincture of knowledge, but—

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Nay, nay, your modeſty is fruitleſs, I know your abilities.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: This eſteem is too obliging, Ladie; but could I ſerve you,
I ſhould value my ſelf too.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Oh Endimion!

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: What means that ſigh?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: You might ſave me the ſhame of being truch-man to't.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: She's in love w'ee.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: By my Aſtrologie I would ſhe were,
On condition I had forfeited all my Intereſt in the ſtars.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: The knowledge y'are ſo envied for
Of my deſires cannot leave you ignorant.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: S'lid, would you have her make love t'ee down-right?
And ſhe'd ſay but half as much to me,
I'd underſtand her, I warrant you:
Y'are the ſtrangeſt Man.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: So you would have had her-a-told us her errand too:
Yes, I warrant you.
Women love to do that they won't ſay;
Some pretty things have but courſe names.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: By that very reaſon, Lady, that you give
For your ſilence, you ought to ſpeak your mind;
If I know a'ready what brings you hither,
Your free declaring it to me ought not
Add any thing to your confuſion.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Excellently well argued! what fending & proving here is?
He's cried up for a wit, and the Wench
Will laugh at him for a fool, a dull one.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: I had beſt talk to her for the credit o'th' houſe.
That ſhe may ſee there's ſome quickneſs
Of apprehenſion i'th' family, ſome feeling left.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: What can the hearing of my weakneſs avail you?
You know the languiſhing deſires I'm preſt withall,
My coming t'ee, my ſtanding thus before you,
Thus bluſhing and diſcountenanc'd, does ſpeak my mind;
Uſe me not then with ſo much cruelty, but ſince
Baſhfulneſs hinders me naming my requeſt,
Do what I would have you, without my ſaying what.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Pray do, Sir, without more bidding.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I ſee, you are not free to ſtrangers, Sir,
I could have made an Intereſt you would not have refus'd
Any courteſie the ſtars make you Maſter of.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: 'Tis clear now; ſome Aſtrologicall queſtion
She has to put me.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Y'are e'en well enough ſerv'd, and't be,
That would not underſtand her other meaning.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.l: She'I ſhift her arrant now, and invent ſomething
To plague you with, I hope.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Would ſhe had made Shift her arrant,
She had ſped better.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Very likely.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Is ſhe mad, to expect I ſhould know her thought?
Am I a Magician, or am I the devil himſelf to do't?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: If it be Aſtrologie, ſome bombaſt words
She cannot underſtand, will quickly put her out of play,

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Unmannerly fellows, they are theſe Conjurers,
They will not ſatisfie a Ladie without ſo much intreatie.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: I'Id e'en leave him, Madam, and go to another▪
What little pyed devil's that, whiſpers with him?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: 'Tis his Man.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: His Zanie, his Jack-Pudding;

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: 'Tis ſome quack this, I warrant you, ſome Mountebank.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Peace, he comes towards us.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Wrap your Anſwer in Fuſtian, Sir, 'tis a warm wear,
And will look gravely.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Not to belye my ſcience, Madam, or uncivilly pretend
An ignorance, you'l not believe me guilty of,
I muſt confeſs, 'tis eaſie ſcrutiny for me
To dive to th' bottom of your heart, and read
What's moſt abſtruſe.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: D'ee ſee now? I knew he could tell.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Yet 'twere in vain I ſhould Endeavour ought
For you, unleſs by a Declaration
Free and ſincere, you teſtify
Your ſull conſent to what I go about;
You would try my skill firſt; but take heed this
Diffidence you ſhrowd with modeſty,
Do not impede the compaſſing your wiſh;
A Frank confidence, a ſtrong credulity
Is required in thoſe apply themſelves
To ſuch as I am for relief; my art's
Beyond the Vulgar of Judiciary Aſtrologers:
Which clearly to evince, I will (if you
Deſire it) tell you what your thought is, now,
This very minute; what brought you hither,
Whether your heart be free, or if engag'd,
To whom, how long y'have liv'd ſo; or what elſe
You think or wiſh moſt ſecret: but this done,
No more; I can do nothing for you then.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: How I ſhall bluſh at this recital, you
Condemn me to?

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: I'ld tell him nothing, and 'twere to me;
Are you ſure he'I keep your counſel?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: What do I ſave by that, when he can know't however?
I love, Endimion; and he that captives me,
Having by Amorous duties won my heart,
Forſakes me then to travel into France,
So ſcornfully, he never takes his leave;
This Letter though I have juſt now receiv'd,
As kind as he was wont to be himſelf,
Which new aſſurance of his love, makes me
Paſſionately now wiſh his return;
I burn to ſee him, and though what I long for
Seem impoſſible, yet am I well aſſur'd
To you 'tis ſo facile, you may this night
Feaſt my ſad Eyes with that beloved ſight.
If ever Love then warm'd your youthful heart,
As your own flames may kindle mutual fire,
Deny not my requeſt.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Here's a requeſt with a vengeance,
Would gravel all the Conjurers of the Realm.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: It had been as eaſie, I ſhould think now,
Taking her up at her firſt weapon,

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I hou doſt run on ſtill with thy own conceit,
And never thinkſt of helping me out of the mire.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Shall I fetch Charles his Wain to draw you out?

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: And yoak Phaebus's horſes to't,
That the Teem may be ſtrong enough.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Call upon Noſtradamus, Sir, he was your Maſter, 〈…〉 (remov'd
He's bound to help you for his own credit.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: The old Man with his hard words was not half ſo terrible.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Tell her, ſhe muſt make a pact with the Devil,
That will skare her.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I know not, Madam, who you take me for,
Nor what you may imagine of my Art,
For where is't like that I this night ſhould find
A Man, that you your ſelf tell me's in France?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: That's a matter of nothing to you,
You do things more prodigious howerly,
I know that, to make one long ſince depriv'd
Of life, both ſpeak and move, is ſlight
And eaſie t'ee; I have it, from good hands.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: No doubt but you have; and I durſt have ſworn.
Y'had bin an eye witneſs yourſelf too
Of ſome of theſe Miracles.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I had rather talk to her o'th influence
Of her Eyes now, then of that o'th Stars.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Oh, had you ſo?
But you are not to chuſe your own Text by
Your favour, Sir, ſhe has ſet you a Theam.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Th' impoſſibility of your requeſt pleads my excuſe,
There is no power in all my Art to ſerve you,
If you command the preſence of an abſent perſon.
Such things are not done by pure Aſtrologie,
Spectres and Phantaſms move by Magick only,
Which black and diſmal ſtudy, as it lies,
Within the compaſs of the Law, ne'r is th' application
Of a noble mind; beſides a Ghoſt or Viſion
Cloath'd in a fantaſtick body, is too melancholly
For your Sex and Age, ſuch dire Apparitions,
As they are full of horror in themſelves,
Strike pale with it, the ſtouteſt looker on,
Your courage would fail you too at ſuch a ſight,
And you'ld repent the courteſie obtain'd.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Oh never, Sir, if the kind Specter have
My beloved's ſhape; be it but like him,
And the ſweet viſion will more pleaſe then fright,
But you miſtruſt me ſtill, and think a Woman
Unfit for ſuch a ſecret.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: He has been very cautious hitherto
Of truſting the Sex with any of that Nature,
And I think he has not many of 'em for you neither.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Nothing leſs, Madam, and ſince you urge me to't,
I have, perhaps, skill enough for what you deſire.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Oh Luce, 'twill come at laſt.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Hang him, Wizzard, I'ld ſee him ſwim to th' Devil
With a Milſtone about his neck, e're I would Court him thus,
Or be beholding to him indeed.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: If I did at firſt plead an impoſſibility
To obey you, 'tis for a certain obſtacle
I find in't, a main one too, your Lover, you tell me,
Is in France, and there's the miſchief on't,
The Sea divides us, and I have no power
Beyond my own diſtrict, the wild Element
So uncontrouledly oppoſes all my charms
My hands are tyed; and that's the true
And only cauſe, I've dallied we'e thus long.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Nay, if that be all, th'impoſſibilitie's none,
That obſtacle of the ſea is eaſily remov'd,
So the freſh water hinder not, and if it do,
We'l croſs the River, this Letter here
Is dated from Dover, ſee.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Nay, I believe you, Madam. worſe and worſe.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: From whence he writes, he'l not ſtir of ſome days,
He wav'd the Packet-boat, and waits a Man of War;
He has ſome buſineſs too in Kent, ſome friends to ſee.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I am gone; this bold Wench with her mettle
Has conjur'd that Devil out of me, others
Think I have at my fingers ends.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Does my Maſter think they take him for a Taylor?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I know he's not ſhip'd yet;

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Would ſhe were ſunk ſome Fathoms with her fellow,
To cool her courage, 'tis ſuch a Virago.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Bellamy's ſuppos'd on's way for France,
What if 'twere he now ſhe long'd for a ſight of?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: That's not unlikely, this may be Celia too;
I'le ſift it out, e're I engage too far.
If he be yet on Engliſh ground, let me
But know his name, for in that Circumſtance
Your Confeſſion's yet defective, not that
I'm ignorant of't, for let me tell you,
Though his Birth be good, his Name as ancient,
The Familie's decay'd in Means, his perſonal
Gallantry making good the worth of Anceſtors
Whoſe I and he ne'r inherited.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: That is his Character.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Nor do we differ much in age, though he
Perhaps, be ſomething of the fairer ſtature.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: It is moſt true.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Nay, then I'm well enough.
You'l think it ſtrange now, when I know the Man,
I ſhould ask you his name, but I have reaſons for't;
Such, as unleſs I have it from your mouth,
I can't comply with your deſires; 'tis an Eſſential
Ceremony, a kind of deference our Art expects.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: How pleaſing 'tis to me to ſpeak that name!
Bellamy, now you have it; what elſe
Muſt I do, or ſay to obtain my ſuit?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: The ſea not awing then my charms▪
There's no pretence left to deny you now;
And were the Task yet harder then it is,
Your Confidence would win me to't,
So daring a Spirit, that ſeeks what hardieſt Men
Durſt not attempt, would ever make me try
My utmoſt, look me full i' th' face.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Oh happy Celia!

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Let me ſee your hand, what day were you born on?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: The Tenth of May.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: What day of the week?
