sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: On a Saturday.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: She does not look, Luce, as ſhe had bin made up
On a Saturday in the afternoon.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: You muſt ſee your Sweet-heart then,

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: To night, if it be poſſible,
The very thoughts of it tranſport me ſo.—

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: You muſt make me a Covenant with his Idea now.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Oh Coſen! will you turn Covenanter now?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: When they that ſet the Idol up
Have pull'd it down themſelves.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Nay, 'Tis burnt, they ſay, 'tis burnt.
He'I make you a Phanatick i' th' end
And you hearken to him, with his idle Idea's.

sp.speaker: Lu
sp.l: As I am here, this is one of the Devils Trapanners,
And has a ſtanding Fee of ſo many freſh
Familiars per annum from the Prince of darkneſs.
To wheedle young ones in.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: This malepert tongue will draw a vengeance on't,
If you beware not, Minion.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: You muſt excuſe her▪ Sir, 'tis a mad Wench,
She will talk thus of her Miſtreſs, or my
Mother, or any one ſometimes.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Your tongue's but little better govern'd neither
For all your excuſes.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Let em talk their fill here among friends,
But not a word of Conjuring abroad▪
D'ee mark me, Gentlewoman, not a word,
Or by my Jacob's-ſtaff—but go to.
The Covenant I deſire is wholly harmleſs,
An innocent Charm, and I muſt needs have
A ticket written with your own hand.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: In bloud, Sir? End. No, no.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Can I refuſe any thing that may contribute
To what I ſo much long for?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: My figure once made, and the Myſtery finiſh'd,
I'le tear your note, indeed I will;
My Standiſh here, and ſome Paper.
sp.stage: they ſet a table with Lights and Paper—

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: What think you now, Luce?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: I think he's a Conjurer ſtill, as I may tell you,
Amongſt our ſelves, for I dare call him ſo
Aloud no more, he ſwears by ſuch a ſtrange thing,
The Prime Miniſter of State to the ſubterranean Monark.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: But what ſayſt thou to my note?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: This very night will he carry it to the
Meeting-houſe, and pin it to the goat's tayl.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: You are ſure i'th' next Lampoons to be coupled
With Lucifer, you ſhall be the ſole couple in hell
For me, I'le nere write to him.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Flat and plain, Miſtreſs, he ſhould have
Nothing under my hand, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Away, away, thou art too ſcrupulous.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Write, as I'le dictate t'ee.
sp.stage: takes her aſide toth' table where ſhe ſits to write

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Shall you & I chop a little Logick now,
My blowing bud of beauty.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: E'en as little as you pleaſe, Sir.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: My moſt undelicate Chambermaid.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: On further acquaintance, you'I ſay, the more the better; for though I ſerve ſuch a terrible Maſter, I can be as familiar, as impudently familiar as any little Rogue of 'em all.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Thou haſt thy ſinful extream too, I ſee.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Yet their Talent lies the more natural way,
I ſhould like it the better of the two,
But thy Maſter is ſo dreadfully learn'd.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Beyond all thou ſeeſt yet;

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: One muſt carry their body ſwimming
With him that knows the heart By looking in the face.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: If he hear but one's name, 'tis enough.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: That's ſtranger yet.
Know people's thoughts, and hear but their names?

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: He never goes without a little devil in's pocket
For that purpoſe, which he calls his Vade mecum:

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: A devil always about him, and you ſerve this man?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Why not? the devil's no ill company ſometimes,
I mean a familiar one:

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Alas, we have whole Covies of tame fiends;
Why there's the devil of Maſcon,
Would you wiſh a more ſociable Goblin?
You have heard of him, the ſtorie's in Engliſh.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: I have not ſeen it.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Why, then I'le tell thee, 'tis a ſmug young fiend
Made love to a Parſon's daughter.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Or his Maid,

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: True, for in that particular Authors diſagree.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: As they do about Statira the Wife of Alexander, whether ſhe were the Daughter, or Widow of King Darius.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Thou art read in Hiſtory too.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Not much.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: But prythee how did the devil court his Miſtreſs,

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Would he do her work for her, as the tales
Go of ſprights and fairies?

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: That I have forgot, but I'le give you the book to ſatiſfie your Curioſity: This I remember, he had a damnable mind to a certain red ribbon ſhe wore ſomewhere; but the niggardly old Parſon would not let her give it him, for which don devil moſt zealouſly reprov'd his want of Charity.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: But what if thy Maſter's devil ſhould creep to my Couſin now?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: How ſhould we be troubled with her at home?

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: That need's not.
A handſome Woman's devil enough of her ſelf,
Beſides by her ſharp look I gueſs her a ſhrew,
She needs no devil to teach her to ſcold.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: She did ſo jet it too as ſhe came in,
So eye her ſelf, I ſee ſhe's proud;
There's another o'th' devils good qualities,
She's not beholding to my Maſter for.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Why, thou ſtudieſt the black art too then?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Phyſiognomie a little, 'tis Phyſiognomie tells all this.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Your name is wanting ſtill, ſubſcribe it, and I've done.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: And is this all?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: All, Madam.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I leave it w'ee: think on me, Endimion;

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I never yet broke promiſe to handſome Lady,
Nor will I now begin with you, fair one.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, don't tell my Coſen, 'twas I had her Apricocks; and I'le ſteal you ſome to morrow, and ſing you a fine ſong too.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Nay, without a bribe I can keep counſel, pretty one.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: I'm undone, if he look me i'th' face now;
I have anger'd him, and theſe Witches are
sp.stage: holds her Apron before her face.
sp.l: So revengeful.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: You hide your face from me now, and I ſee your heart.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Oh, Sir, I'le never call you Conjurer more,
Nor ſpeak true word of you again, but if
You know what I now think, as you are frail
Your ſelf, keep it from my Miſtreſs, ſhe'd turn
Away Ralph infallibly, and ſhe knew it.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: How much ado have I had to ſhake her off?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: You have been ſomething long about it indeed.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: This bold cheat will fame you ſtraight
For eminently skill'd;
And your renown will every where increaſe.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I never ſuffer'd ſo hot a perſecution.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Nor I ſo tedious an Expectation.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I'm ſure I ſweat for't again.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: I durſt not laugh neither.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: How modeſtly he declin'd her commendations? and yet the very careleſneſs you received 'em with, perſwaded her, you thought you well deſerv'd 'em.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Why harp'd you not on the Ceremonious ſtring ſtill?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I ſaw ſhe came not for a Compliment.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Why ſtruck you not in, in your adviſor's way?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Leſs on that account too.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: That was the Common road.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: It was not hers, you ſee.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: I never was ſo put to't contein my ſelf,
As when ſhe prov'd her Lover was on Engliſh ground,
And whip'd off the ſalt water.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I confeſs, I was put to't my ſelf then;
I was almoſt non-pluſt.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: I hearkned ſtill when ſhe'd beſpeak a bridge
Over to Callice; but what if we had
Not been in an Iſland now? what if there
Had been ſome way over Land into France.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: If there had, 'tis odds ſhe'd not find it out;
For 'twere I think another wonder, ſhe
Should be more knowing in Coſmographie,
Then I am in Aſtrologie:
At worſt I had found out ſome other Evaſion,
Pleaded the difference of Religion—

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Marry, and a good plea too.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Or I know not what my ſelf now.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: I think ſo; but the letter, what's that?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: No ſecret; but prythee
Who ſhould this Mother be the young one mention'd once,

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Oh the Widow Aunt, I told you Celia liv'd with.

body.l: Bellamy I know where you are,
Pretence of travels, vain and light.
And you are not yet got ſo farre,
But I may ſee you here this night.

sp.l: A moſt elaborate Epiſtle, full of rithme and reaſon:
And much you can do with it no doubt.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: We muſt convey it into Bellamy's hands,
Who ſuſpecting by 't he has been dogg'd, or
Is found out indeed, will haſt to Celia
For his vindication, and ſo betray
Himſelf; I am reveng'd by this means of
Clarinda, whoſe night-works I deſtroy: and
If it happen that Celia full of ſpirits ſtill
And apparitions, take him for one, and
Dare not give him hearing, no trick, no plot
We could contrive, will add more credit to
What's of my Aſtrologie already ſpread.
All the buſineſs is to deliver this note.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Leave that, Sir to my care

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Your care? is that a fit Province
For a Raw-man? I'le take charge on't my ſelf.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Nay, no Vying; I muſt uſe you another way,
But it muſt be delivered to his own hands.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: So I intend it ſhall. End. But how?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Without much cunning thus: Clarinda waits
Him in her garden to night, tis near the
Hour too, in's road I'le lye perdu, and if
I do not make lam change his Rendezvous.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: No better way could be imagin'd.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Diſpatch then, and bring us tydings on't.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: That I ſhall ſpeedily, and good one's too, nere fear it.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: GOod Sir, nay, but conſider.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: The more I do, the more I find you a trouble ſome fellow.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: But I always was of your midnight Counſels,

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: And that blazes 'em abroad at noon-day.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: Was I ever heard to ſay, my Maſter has left ſuch a Ladie, ſuch a one's his Miſtriſs now; he treated this Madam at that place, and t'other Madam at t'other place?—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: If you had, ſirrah, I had been ſeen to beat you.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: Nay, nay, I don't talk o'that; there's no bodie queſtions your aptneſs that way.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Will you get you home?

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: After you is manners, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I ſhall beat you home.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: What again beating? ſome other time, ſome other time may ſerve, you have buſineſs of more concern in hand now to my Knowledge.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Your Knowledge?

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: You ſleep not all day, to ramble all night for nothing.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Ramble, ſirrah?

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: Nay, I obſerve you, when I don't follow you? 'tis for no good you hide your ſelf from Madam Celia thus. She has deſerv'd Better of you; who did I bring you the Two hundred pounds from, when you were ſnapt at Mr Grogram's ſuit of Pater-Noſter-Row? Or who fills your Pockets again when your Dice run the children of lee, or Deuce ace is your Comfort? Many a Ladie has more comfort of a cheaper Gallant.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Are you that Ladie's Dun, Sir?

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: Her kindneſs will ſoon ha▪ done, and 't be no better requited, then are we undone.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Excellent! quibbles too.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: You may get preferment however i'th' next forlorn expedition: 'twill be ſad reducing your Coach, Horſes, and Lacqueys to a ſixty pound per annum Equipage.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Thou art my Pedagogue ſure, my Tutour.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: I am your poor Valet de Chambre, Sir; one that would gladly have his Maſter wiſe enough to grow rich, that he may thrive under him: refuſe a handſome Ladie, and a good fortune, when they are offer'd, to ferret after Je we ſcay quoy's?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Thou haſt not thy name for nothing, I ſee; th' art e▪en the Rude Serving-man, it ſpeaks thee.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: I am honeſt, Sir, if I am bold, I do not flatter and cheat you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: One of 'em I'le ſwear thou do'ſt not; but for the other, Rud, I'le ſwear,

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I ſhan't be rid of this fellow now, and aſide. Looks on's watch. my hour draws near. I know him cloſe and ſecret as the night, however I ſeem ſhie of him. Come, I will truſt thee for once; as we go, I'le tell thee whither; but follow me, d'ee hear, and direct me not.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: Oh any thing, Sir, to make one.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: This fellow's one of thoſe are ſcandaliz'd at all wickedneſs they have not a hand in, and cannot abide any Man ſhould Drink or Wench without 'em.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: And ſome ſuch exploit, I ſuſpect you bound for now.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I ſhould gueſs you do by your earneſtneſs to make one.
Nay, this way, this way.

div.head: SCENE III. The back-ſide of Sr Chriſtopher's Garden.

sp.p: I Long to have done my arrant now, to ſee how heartily, how gameſter like, he'll fret to looſe the kiſſes he thinks himſelf ſo fair for to night? how many ten groats will he ſwear himſelf out of, if any of the godly be but within hearing? I muſt pack as ſoon as I have deliver'd the Letter, for coming in Celia's name, the thanks he'd give, won't be worth ſtaying for. I cannot be far from the Garden now, here will I ſtand ſentinel: he knows me not, and ſo there is no danger of an after-beating.
I hear ſome bodie, 'tis he certainly.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: Nay, if Clarinda love you too, I'm ſatisfied, ſhe's rich enough to do our buſineſs, but here's a father's good will to get; the other's at her own diſpoſe.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Time may work him▪ who's there?

div.stage: runs againſt Sh. as going into the garden

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: A friend, Sir, that waited your coming:
This note from Celia ſpeaks my buſineſs,
She earneſtly deſires your Company to night:
And I am your Worſhip's ſervant.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: An unſerviceable one, he thinks, at this time.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What curſt Encounters this? honeſt fellow, Friend, prythee a word. Rudeman, ſtay the fellow.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: He's gone, he's out of my reach; but that's no hard matter indeed, for I never had any great reach with me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Venturing at wit, when I am thus perplext.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.p: The night's ſo dark too, he's as ſoon out of ſight.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Again?

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: What devil has diſcover'd you were in town?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Or what faithleſs confident rather betrays
My ſecret? 'tis Gratian, it can be none
But he, I truſted none elſe, and he loves
Celia too,
In whoſe affection to ſupplant me now,
He has betray'd my privacie:
I have deſerv'd no leſs to truſt a Rival;
That title once ſucceeding diſſolves
All former tyes of friendſhip.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: To be ſnap'd here too at the garden door
Brings Clarinda in queſtion.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: That's meer accident; Gratian, though he knew
I conceal'd my ſelf, knew not wherefore,
And ſhe would nere betray me.
Some ſpeedy balſome though I muſt apply
Where he has us'd ſuch Corroſives: I will
To Celia, ſhe loves me, with eaſe I can
Pacifie her, and deſtroy thoſe raſh hopes
A falſe friend has conceiv'd.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: But what iſ this note were not from Celia now?

div.stage: ſtayes him as he was going off.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: The Meſſenger I know not,
Nor had he any mind I ſhould.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: So farre it ſmells knaviſhly.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Firſt let me ſee, if't be her hand, and then
With all the kind words, Credulous Maids lend
Greedy ear unto, I will make my peace.
If light diſcover it a miſtake, or trick,
I'le forward to Clarinda, where
A thouſand kiſſes ſhall make amends
For ſtaying thus beyond my hour?

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: Marry, would I were to do the penance for you.

div.head: SCENE IV. Celia's Chamber. A Table and Lights ſet forth, a Chair by't.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: CAn you imagine this ſtar-wright with all his hard words, ſhould bring Bellamy ſo far on ſuch a ſudden?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Silly wretch! thy ſhallow underſtanding
Cannot reach the bottom of his Capacity,
Which, (ſo the ſea lye not in's way) will do
A thouſand things harder and ſtranger, he'll
Come then, never doubt it, not he himſelf
'Tis true, but his ſimilitude,
Something reſembling him ſo perfectly,
Love it ſelf could not make a diſtinction.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: What good will that Copy of his Countenance do you?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Ask Love if thou be'ſt ignorant, for he is
The reaſon of all he forces us to,
Nor is the Curioſity ſo ſtrange,
In me, nor ſo particular;
I've heard of many Women uſe the like.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: 'Twere a ſtrange thing indeed Women in this town would not venture upon. I have heard too of the Woman of Billeter-Lane, and of her of Grub-ſtreet.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: And of Ladies that go into Chancery-Lane to know when their husbands will die, whether their next will be kinder.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: And what day o'th' week is beſt to be married on: but bleſs me from ſuch pranks, they are no handſome leans melancholy on the table. one's, I'm ſure, though the handſome Ladies uſe 'em.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: But, Madam, you are heavie, the very thought
Of this apparition, works upon you
Like th' expectation of an ague-fit.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Shall I ſing you a ſong, Coſen, to divert ſad thoughts?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I prythee, Fannie, 'twill chear thee,
However it work on me.

lg.l: Thus the white bull that does Europa bear
Shrouding Jove's perſon does his Love defect:
Send him to Danae in a ſhower.
If 'mong the gods he bear this ſway,
What can he not o're Mortals doe?
He that with Deities thus dares to play,
Will govern ſure Mankind as ſtrangely too:
Nor is the fairer ſex more free

sp.l: For women once:—

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I'le hear no more; there's none ſo ſtrange as mine,
As that my Bellamy's expected in,
Others had the ſubſtances they lov'd, though
Cloath'd with accidents they were not us'd to,
But I muſt be content with th'outward ſhape
Of what I love, ſhrouding I know not what
Subſtance or reality.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: But if it be a Phantaſm, a bodie
Patch'd up of air or groſſer Vapours,
Will not you be afraid, think you?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Not in the leaſt.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: I'm ſure but I ſhall then.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Heark, ſome bodie knocks at door.

div.stage: ſtarting off the table ſhe lean'd on.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Some bodie, quoth you?
We neither look for bodies nor ſouls here,
What if 'twere the I know not what now?
The ſtrange thing you'l call Bellamy?
You grow pale already, you ſigh too.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Is this the Courage love puts into his?
I think he's a Coward himſelf for my part
And he back you with no better mettle now in time of need.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: You think 'tis he now.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I am not certain, but ſee who ere it be.
I'm ſtrangely chang'd o'th' ſudden, I feel not
That firm reſolution now, my ſoul is
Seiz'd with horrour, that ſtrikes a ſhivering cold
All o're my body, ſomething there is in
Nature ſtill repugns againſt theſe Viſions,
Maugre the love or humour ſets one on.
But what need I fear?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Oh Madam, Madam, 'tis he, 'tis Bellamy,
sp.stage: drops the candle out of her hand and runs away.
sp.l: But that he's twice as tall as he was wont to be.

sp.speaker: Cel. Fan.
sp.l: Ay me! Ay me!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: What means this ſhreeking and this running about?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Now am I well paid for my Curioſity, I have at the far ſide of the ſtage. my wiſh, and 't proves my own undoing, 'tis Bellamy's Voice, but I han't power to anſwer him.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: I'm nothing miſtaken in my ſelf,
sp.stage: from under the table, where ſhe had hid her ſelf.
sp.l: I knew I ſhould be afraid, and my Coſen
For all her cracking proves as very a Coward.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: When I beſought th' Aſtrologer to ſend him to me,
I wiſht to ſee him onely, not to ſpeak with him.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Send for me, Celia, and uſe me thus. 'tis ſomething ſtrange?

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: If the thing ſhould find me under the table now.
I'le pray hard.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Could you find no body elſe to practiſe
Theſe Exotick fits upon? muſt I be
Your ridiculous mirth, that bring my Celia
New aſſurances, 'tis ſhe alone
Has power in Bellamy's heart?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I'le ha none of thee, nor thy heart,
I abhor the power, 'tis the true Bellamy I had a mind to ſee.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: She ſuſpects my inconſtancy;
I am to Celia the ſame Bellamy ſtill,
My thoughts of thee are nothing chang'd, I vow.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Fiend keep off, avant Phantaſm; get runs into her cloſet, and ſhuts her ſelf in. thee to France again, or into Lapland, from whence thou cameſt, I think.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Hear but my reaſons. is't rallerie this?
Or ſome trick devis'd on purpoſe to make
Trial of me? Fannie, what doe'ſt thou there?

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Help, help, I'm kill'd, I'm done to death getting haſtily from under it. with fear.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Was ever Gallant thus gallantiz'd?
sp.stage: throws it down candle and all, runs away and leaves him i'th' dark.
sp.l: The devil o-love, and this be it, I ſay.
Fiend, and Phantaſm, and Lapland! I am not
Mad ſure, though they be; I'le try'em again;
Luce, Celia, why Luce, prythee prevail with
Thy Miſtreſs to hear me. Celia, Fannie,
Pretty, Sweet Fannie: 'tis labour loſt;
I ſhan't be anſwer'd, unleſs there be an
Eccho within hearing, the dumb devil
Poſſeſſes 'em, and I am left i'th' dark
To grope out the meaning of this frolick.
Well, let her have her humour, I muſt to
Clarinda, and prevent what ill offices may be
There intended too, I am diſcovered
In town, and need not now keep out of ſight,
Pray heaven the morn prove kinder then the night.

div.head: The firſt SCENE, Sr Chriſtopher's houſe.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: SO deep a melancholy does both ſurprize,
And grieve me, Sweet; what makes theſe ſighs ſo frequent?
Can you doubt my fidelity?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I'm full of fears, I muſt confeſs it, Bellamy;
Nor can I, when I think what enemies we have,
Though you are preſent, force a chearfulneſs.
What will not Endimion, knowing all
We thought moſt ſecret, attempt to ruine us:

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: He can do nothing, if you love me ſtill.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Would I could ſay ſo of Celia too!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Oh Madam! you are too injurious—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Our firſt affections nere looſe all their power;
Call your kindneſs for her a civil devoir,
A gratitude if you will; ſhe is lovely ſtill,
And Civility forces you to ſee her:
Then ſmother'd flames too-eaſily break out.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Wrong not your own charms, and my affection
With ſo unjuſt a Jealouſie:
If you can ſo much ſlight Clarinda's power
To fear Celia; I'le not ſee her at all.
But I am not without my fears neither,
For who loves tenderly, and thinks himſelf ſecure?
What will your father ſay, when once he knows
You ſuffer Bellamy's love, or what will
He not do to ruine a happineſs
He thinks me not rich enough to deſerve?
He'll chide, he'll ſchool Clarinda, he'll threaten her,
If ſhe neglect his leſſons, will ſhe not
Fear his anger? and in that fear, in that
Fear perhaps ſhe will forſake me,
And wrought of his own mind, hold it
A madneſs where an Eſtate is wanting,
To value Birth, deſcent, or Breeding—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Think better of me, then ſo. Know that the
Vertue of the belov'd object alone
Is enough to make me conſtant, that worth
Which firſt made me love, makes me perſever.
Nor is my heart ſo much a ſlave to fear,
That Menaces can blot out an Image,
A noble affection had drawn in't.
No Bellamy, I ſhall wear yours here ſtill.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I am too happy then.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Accept this pledge of my fidelity,
And be aſſur'd I'm yours;
Let friends, let fortune ſmile or frown,
Never ſhall Celia's conſtancy equal mine.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: My Joy is now ſo great, I am loſt in't.
Unable to ſpeak, unable to keep ſilence—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: You muſt keep it a while; here's my father—

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Is not that Bellamy? what return'd alreadie?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: An unexpected Law-ſuit forces me back,
I am ſub-pena'd up again, and muſt
Till after term at leaſt lay by all thoughts
Of ſeeing France; I was at Canterbury.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: And how does my Nephew Manly?

sp.speaker: Reat.
sp.l: He may as well ask me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: He entertain'd me nobly at his houſe.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Has not the young-ſquire written to me? ha?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: He had, and gave me his letter, but a
French Lacquey I took here for the Journey,
When he ſaw me turn back, run away with
My Vallize, and your letter was in it.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: That Lacquey ſaves thy credit now,
It muſt have been ſaid to thee elſe.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: You have made but an ill journey on't then.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Thus are my ſtars ſtill inauſpicious to me.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Endimion Madam at your requeſt would
Tell him to his Vallize again.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Away thou cruel Wench, thou ſeeſt the pangs
This diſcourſe gives me, and canſt raiſe mirth out of it?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: My ownloſs I ſhould not value,

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: 'Twas not ſo great indeed.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: But the Letter was meerly writ on my behalf,
And did implore your aid in my affairs.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: You may command me, and my intereſt.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: If you Eſpouſe his Cauſe, he need not fear being caſt.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: If the old Man Eſpouſe his Cauſe,
The young one will Eſpouſe you.

sp.speaker: Rud.
sp.l: And that's it ſhe would be at.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Would 'twere come to't once for me,
That I might have ſome quiet among 'em.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: On your favour then I build my hopes, but this
Law-buſineſs draws me uncivilly away,
Pleaders are not Maſters of their own time.
Your pardon, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Buſineſs muſt be waited on;

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: May I preſume you'I mind your father
Of my ſuit, Madam, and contribute
To the continuance of his favours?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Ile do my beſt, Sir, to poſſeſs him with
The juſtice of your cauſe; his Example
Authorizes me to own your intereſt too.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: But wilt thou be thus melancholy ſtill?
What is the cauſe? tell me, good Clarinda.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I know no reaſon for't.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: She dreamt of a younger brother, Sir, to night,
Which, reflecting on Endimions prediction,
Seems ominous.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Your bolt is ſoon ſhoot ſtill.
Art indiſpos'd in health?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I feel no alteration;
And yet it may be ſome natural overſlow
Of a dull humour in the bodie cauſes this heavineſs.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Ah Clarinda! my tenderneſs of thee
Is ill requited with this ſullen reſerve
Of thy ſick thoughts..

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: To ſpeak truth, I have loſt ſome toyes, and that's
The onely reaſon I can give for this damp
My mirth is ſtruck withall.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Why, what haſt loſt?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: That which does vex me much.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: But what?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: The Roſe-diamond you gave me.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Let not that trouble thee, it may be found again.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I have ſmall hopes on't, I have ſought every where.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: I was careleſly laid by perhaps,
And opportunity makes a true man a thief:
sp.p: But the loſs is eaſily repair'd, there are fairer rings in town, I'le go buy thee one preſently.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: That were a ſlight reparation of my loſs;
I fancied this.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: What a fondneſs is here? though I give her
A better ring, ſhe'l looſe by the bargain:
Well, ſet thy heart at reſt,
Thou ſhalt have thy own again, for I will
Juſt now to Endimion about it.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Now you are in a fine Pickle!
To excuſe theſe dumps y'are faln into,
Y'have gone and ſpoilt all.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: So I have indeed.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Peace, peace; he's coming back.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Tell me, when was this ring loſt?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I miſt it but to day.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: So, ſo, 'tis not gone farre, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Further I hope, then your diſcoverie will reach.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: The old man's here again.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.p: But about what a clock was it loſt? for I ſhall be askt all theſe queſtions, that I ſhall; therefore I muſt be prepar'd.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Between eight and nine.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Oh 'tis well, 'tis well, eight and nine, eight and nine;
Let me not forget eight and nine.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: How he maunders it, eight and nine, eight and nine; he'l Con his leſſon nine times over, but he'l have it perfect.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: What ſhall I do, Beatrix? adviſe me, good Beatrix.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: 'Twere well and you would be adviz d, before▪
You do it, then Beatrix could ſay ſomething,
But to be put ſtill to an after-game,
You are ſo wilfully fore-handed:
This ſcurvy Aſtrologer now will tell him all.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Endimion is the Man indeed undoes me▪
But let him do his worſt, my love ſtands not
In awe now of a father's check, 'tis of
So fair a growth his frowns cannot nip it,
My heart is Bellamy's, nothing can force it from him,
Endimion and his Stars are all too weak?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: The devil is not ſo head-ſtrong as theſe young Wenches, when they have got a bit of a Man; but 'tis I muſt lay the ſtorm for all her vapouring; I muſt let Shift know how things go, leaſt his Maſter be put to't beyond his skill, and ſhaking hands with Aſtrologie, be forced to tell our old man the plot.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: WHat a perpleity am I reduc'd to?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Why, 'twas with your conſent,

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Nay, by your own order we rais'd the report.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Yes of Aſtrologie, but of nothing elſe,
And yet they think abroad, I have all hell
At command: They point at me i'th ſtreets,
So noted a perſon I am.
There goes the learned Man, ſaies one; oh the
Aſtrologer, ſaies another, that comes
And peeps me in my face to know me again.
In ſome places they ſtare at me,

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: As they would have done at the hairy woman,
Had ſhe not cas'd her beard up as ſhe went about.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Right—or as they did at the Hermophrodite T'other day at the play.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: The Prophet, ſaies a preciſe one, and lifts
His hands and eyes to Heaven in admiration,
That one ſo young ſhould be ſo knowing.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Children run away, and cry the Witch, the Witch, the Witch; becauſe at home their Mothers fright them with him.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Thou boy, Rawman!

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Some underſtanding ones there are, (and thoſe
I forgive, becauſe they are i'th' right)
Believe me guilty of no Magick, but
A meer Impoſtor, for ſuch contemn me,
Laugh at me, and thoſe that think me other.
Thus am I entertain'd i'th' ſtreets;
Or thus at leaſt I interpret their looks
And actions that I meet i'th' ſtreets.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Some skill you have in Phyſiognomy,
It ſeems, (if you have none in Aſtrologie)
That can read all this in Men's faces.
But fame, you know, loves to augment every thing.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Nothing toth' People is a little rare,
They will hyperbolize, and skrue all novelties
To the higheſt Key: a lye with them
Snow-ball-like rowles about, and gets in every place,
Each teller of't adds ſomething of his own,
To ſhape it to his fancie.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: If you are thus plagu'd abroad, you muſt keep
Home a while; the Wonder will be over.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: We cannot do that neither in quiet,
So many have found his Lodging out;
And now Moll Cut-purſe that Oracle of felonie
Is dead, there's not a pocket pickt,
But hee's acquainted with it.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: That's much indeed.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Nor a ſilver hilt pincht away, but they come
To the figure-flinger for it.
sp.p: He hears of every Wedding, Chriſtning, City-feaſt, by th' Butlers recourſe to him for Plate and Linnen they loſt at 'em.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: That's more yet.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.p: Alas, I am a kind of grandiſſime Jurie, and have all thefts brought before me, before they go to Hicks-hall, or the Old Baily; marry, could I help the Man to his Mare again, they would never go thither, and I might take much of the matter out of the Lawyers hands: but all Trades muſt live, I'le not ſpoil theirs. I ſhall have the Country-fellows too with the ſavoury queſtions that poz'd old Noll's ſtar-peeper, then am I in a ſweet condition.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: The World is ſatisfied with your skill, 'tis grown a full and general perſuaſion.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: I ſee nothing but mirth the ſtratagem has yet produc'd.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.p: What? to have Sir, and Madam; Cut and Long-tail put me a hundred ſeveral queſtions, as if I were Jupiter hammon, or Diana's ſpokes-man at Epheſus? you reckon this nothing? I never had too much of nothing till now.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Your Miſtreſs by this fiction's aw'd,
Your Rival fears you too,
Their pleaſures are diſturb'd,
And all ſucceeds as you could wiſh it ſhould.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Believe it Lewis, 'tis without regret
That I give Bellamy place, the diſturbance
I bring his pleaſures, yeilds me no content;
My own flames extinct, it concerns not me
Whether Clarinda meet his love, or no.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Here's an indifferencie I look'd not for.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.p: In affairs of love I meaſure ever the Eſteem I make of Women, by that they make of me; where they incline to kindneſs, I can love too: if they withdraw once, or refuſe their favours, my flexible and obedient heart, Lewis, can ſoon imitate: nor ever need I fower and twenty howers to cure my ſelf of that diſeaſe.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: I did miſtake your temper; but ſince 'tis ſo convenient, why own'd you not the truth of all at firſt, without taking the Aſtrologer upon you?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: You'l wonder at my ſtupiditie;
Nor can I now my ſelf conceive, why I
Run my neck into this nooze, when all the danger
That threatned, was but the turning away
Of a Chamber-maid.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Nere let it trouble you now, we bear our
Share of all, and owe a helping hand to
Bring you out, We help'd to plunge you in, and
Half the ſhame will fall on the divulgers.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I have a quarrel to you, Endimion.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Here's my Virago again, 'tis th' importuneſt
Wench this, ſhe'l never be anſwered. How can
I ſince laſt night have deſerved your anger?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: If Bellamy has not been abſent, why
Would you, whoſe rare knowledge extends it ſelf
To ſecrets more remote, make me one of
His being in town?
Why dealing with that candor you ſeem'd to
Promiſe, did you not tell me where he was?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: What reaſon ſhall I give her? oh! I knew
It not my ſelf till I made my figure;
Yet what if I had known it ſooner? I
Promis'd but a ſight of Bellamy, and
Did you not ſee him? conſider but with
Equal Eyes the whole adventure,
No part of it but to my credit turns;
For if in lieu of an illuſion, Madam,
A ſhade, a Phantaſm you expected,
Spight of the care he took to hide himſelf,
I forc'd him though in perſon to appear,
Does it not prove the certain influence
Of an art.
You cannot now with want of power tax?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: It does, I muſt confeſs, it does; this reaſon
Deſtroyes all Jealouſies I had of it.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: You may be ſure 'tis the beſt
He could find out for you oth' ſudden.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: But give my paſſion yet ſome further eaſe;
This Bellamy, this fair friend playes me fowl,
Thoſe Vows forgot, I too much credited,
Pays a new Miſtreſs what is due to me.
I have the ſtorie of their cloſe Amours,
And know the ſtars alone, which you command,
Witneſs their meetings and their kindneſſes:
Break me this league then learned Endimion,
You that nere meet with obſtacle to your will
But what your art orecomes;
Cancel the bonds ſhe has my faithleſs in,
I'th' midſt of her Careſſes force him from
Her eyes; reſtore him to his true Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: No evaſion does the Learning ſhe ſo much admires
Inſpire me now, but to perſwade her ſhe's miſtaken.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Something from the learned Endimion will
Be expected, but that I think may ſerve

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Take better thoughts of your Lover, Madam:
Though in his carriage he may be too blame,
Yet are you miſinform'd of what keeps him
In town, you are the cauſe of it your ſelf,
To cure his Jealouſie he thus plays leaſt in ſight,
And to obſerve you does pretend this Journey;
But ſince you are thus conſtant to him ſtill,
Fear not his leaving you:
And ſhould you of his Love want other proofs,
Let this ſuffice, that he is Jealous grown,
With a ſeeming coldneſs,
Or neglect perhaps he may diſſemble
A while, but let it not diſquiet you,
For 'tis you he loves, I ſay again,
And paſſionately.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Pleaſing hopes! comfortable aſſurance?
Pardon dear Bellamy if without Cauſe
I queſtion'd thus thy faith; if Jealouſie
Muſt prove thy Love, let my fears aſſure thee of mine,
I fear'd to looſe but what I love to keep.
The heavens, kind Endimion, powre as many
Bleſſings on you, as y'have aſſur'd me of.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: She payes you in your own coin; as you have
Pleas'd her with an aſſurance of nothing,
She requites you with a wiſh of as much.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: 'Tis as believing a good Soul
As you'ld wiſh to preach to.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: And as well ſatisfied y'have ſent her away,
Her heart I dare ſwear's as light as her head.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Her requeſt did not much fright me this bout,
I knew that for a few fair words I ſhould
Be rid of her credulous Ladieſhip.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: But how intend you to make good your word
To Gratian? it ſeems alreadie broke by
The hopes y'have given Celia.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Why perceive you not thoſe hopes are airie
Nothings with which I flatter her forwardneſs
To be fool'd? I know Clarinda
Has Bellamy too faſt, to think
He ever will be Celia's, and this knowledge
Made me ſpeak my own belief to Gratian.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Nay, he believes you too, and looks on me
His Introducer t'ee, as bound in honour for your performance,
Yet how you will, or can, I'm ſtill to ſeek.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: In Love you are indeed.
Would you not judge elſe, that Celia
Needs muſt ſee at laſt how Bellamy fools her,
That ſhe'l grow wearie of being thus abus'd?
If your friend then prove conſtant and perſever;
Will not his ſervices reach her heart i'th end?
Now if he give my art th' honour of an
Event, is due to his own induſtry
And the common Courſe of things,
The ſtars be prais'd for it,
But now we are free from theſe fortune ſeekers,
Let's breath a while, and talk of ſomething elſe.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Not ſo free as you think neither; here's one—

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Is worſe then twenty Celia's.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Maſter Endimion.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Oh Sir! what wind blows you hither?

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: An ill wind ſure.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I thought ſo.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: But you will make it take about, and blow
Every one their own again, I muſt entreat
One Curteſie of you, kind Gentleman.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: What is it?

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.p: Excuſe my boldneſs if I deal thus freely with you, and come to the point without any further compliment or preamble, I uſe no Ceremonie amongſt friends?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I commend you for it, a civil freedom is much better.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.p: The loſs of a certain Diamond has cauſed great diſorder at home, my ſervants are ſuſpected, and the whole family being in diſturbance about it, my humble requeſt is, you'l help me to ſet the ſaddle on the right ho • ſe, that is you'l caſt a figure for't, and tell who has it.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: The old Man comes in very good time to to End. break the truce you would have made with Aſtrologie.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I muſt break all commerce with it,
The chear s too groſs to laſt above a day;
I ever told you ſo.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: He's muſing on my requeſt now.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: The trade he drives requires great recollection, 'tis a ſpeculative trade, and I have often ſeen him on ſuch occaſions in ſo deep a ſtudy, you'ld think the ſoul did quite forſake the body, 'tis leſt ſo void of action.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.p: He had more need to ſet all wheels awork, he muſt climb up to th' heavens for my ring, he'l nere find it here below elſe.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.p:
I am not quit now for gulling an Amorous Maid, to Lew. or a more ignorant Lover, I muſt fool a man, who in that very toy I fool him with pretends to be as skill'd, as I am unacquainted,
and will diſcover my ignorance as ſoon as I pretend to knowledg. No, no, 'tis my own undoing to aſide Lew and B. ſlighting him. play upon him any longer. I muſt deal freely, 'tis the onely way to get out of this plunge.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: See but what pains he takes.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: He's about your buſineſs all this while.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.p: He begins to look ſomething ſeriouſly upon the matter.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Having no Intereſt to delude you, Sir;
I muſt confeſs there is much more believ'd,
Or ſaid of me, then I deſerve: 'tis true,
I have read ſomething of Aſtrologie,
And view'd the grounds your Artiſts work upon,
Which makes ſome talking friends boaſt they have ſeen
Experiments beyond the common, though indeed
I ne're gave the leaſt ſign of a skill, they
Needs will force upon me, unleſs in words
Sometimes, yet ſparingly, when their Example
Forc'd a compliance: but with you
I proteſt again, the reputation
This fiction gets me, nor all the merry
Conſequences of it, can ne're force me
To ſuch forgery; as for your Diamond then,
In vain expect you tydings of't from me,
'Tis out of my reach believe it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: He will fall to his natural Level
Of ignorance, I ſee, do what we can.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: And yet he cannot reſolve to confeſs himſelf
An Impoſtor neither; he minces it a little.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.p: Did I not know by the report of others, you are this day the Phoenix of Aſtrologers; this very humility with which you depreſs you abilities, would raiſe you in my Eſteem above the common rank of Scholars.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Leave an opinion, I m not ſo happy
To deſerve, I know nothing in the ſtars.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Who could forbear laughing at this old fellow, aſide. that makes him take more pains to perſwade his ignorance, then others do to get knowledge.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: This very earneſtneſs with which you decline
The title of a knowing Man, tells me
Tis your due, and confirms me more and more
In the belief of your capacity.
Thus modeſt, thus diſcreet are they always
Who know much, nor will they, by aſſuming
Worth unto themſelves, derogate from what
They do deſerve, or by ſuch groſs Vanity
Eclypſe the Luſtre of their rare Endowments.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Our Aſtrologer has a fine time on't.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: You wiſh your ſelf in his place, I warrant.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: No, no, I have my ſhare of the paſs-time,
Where I am.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Were I indeed the Man you take me for,
Though I had reaſon to conceal my ſelf from others,
Here I would yield my intereſt up to yours,
And with candour lay open all my skill,
But I have none, none at all to merit
The honour you doe me.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.p: I tell you again, that this humility alone is more commendable in you, then all your learning; he that knows moſt knows himſelf too well to be proud of what he knows, he ſees too much daily to learn, to think that much he has alreadie learnt: and thus what art ſoever one pretend to, he that dares boaſt himſelf a Maſter of it, knows nothing in't at all.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.p: Lyars, they ſay, looſe credit even for the few truths they utter; but mine is a ſtranger puniſhment, when I lyed I was credited; and now I ſpeak truth, I cannot win belief.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.p: But to come to my ring again, I muſt tell you (if that be a neceſſary Circumſtance▪ 'twas a gift of my poor Wife's, for whoſe ſake I long kept it, till at laſt Clarinda got it of me, and ſhe bas loſt it this morning, as ſhe thinks, 'twixt eight and nine.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: You ſhall have the other too at night, Sir.
Heark hither, this is but a pretext.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Why makes he ſo fine of it?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: Hee's affraid perhaps of being ſuſpected of Witchcraft; 'tis a detracting age, and he had need be cautious.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.p: He's over-nice with me, I can keep Counſel, and would conceal what were not fit for every Ear.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: This did Beatrix tell me juſt now.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Th' intelligence comes luckily, I was caught elſe.
Pardon the freedom, Sir, I take, to leave you
For an account of buſineſs I had ſent
My man about, I ſhould not treſpaſs thus,
But that it did require ſome haſt.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.p: Would you had treſpaſs'd, that you might expiate it With the Curteſy I requeſt.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I am provided for him now,
And ſince he has a mind to 't, have at him;
Had I but skill enough.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Skill enough for a ring? away, away;
sp.p: There's nothing eaſier, then to help one again to ſuch a toy as that, I could have don't my ſelf at your years:

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I muſt yield by degrees, he'l ſuſpect me,
If I paſs ſuddenly from one extream
To another. Sir, I proteſt again
Without diſſimulation—

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Without diſſimulation, or procraſtination,
Good Sir, tell me to my ring again;
For I know you can, if you liſt now?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I did but ſpare you ſome trouble, declining
Thus to tell you what I find;
But ſince you needs will have it,

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.p: Tell me, tell me, 'tſhall ne're trouble me, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: He that this morning ſaluted you in
A riding garb, is the Man; he has it.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.p: Who would have ſuſpected him of all the world? that a Man of his birth and breeding ſhould play ſuch pranks, Neceſſity perhaps drives him to't;

And that We know having no Law it ſelf, makes thoſe that feel it, Lawleſs too. You ſee Endimion, how much in vain you go about to hide that, which in your very looks I read; when
once, I ſay, That Man's a Wit, a Scholar, he's one indeed. But fare you well Sir, I'le go after my ring.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: You ſtuck ſcurvily, till Shift helpt you out.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Never more, I ſwear; I knew not what ſhift to make.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: 'Twas well for you there was one made to your hand.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Marry, was it.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: But what if he fall out with Bellamy now,
As having ſtoln his ring?

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Nay, what if he charge him with felonie?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: And the Conſtable with him?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: That were a jeſt indeed.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: What matter whether he take him for a ſon-in-law, or a thief, 'tis much at one; both lye at the catch for the old Man's Money, both (if 'tis not otherways to be had) watch his death for it.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Though hitherto the ſport does mainly thrive;
Checkt by no obſtacle but ſuch, as the
Removal of, turns to increaſe of mirth,
I'm wearie of a trade I nere was 'prentice to;
To leave it then with credit as I drive
It on, ſince the perſuaſion of my
Knowledge makes this old Man believe
What e're I ſay, I'le work on his facility
To a noble end, and farre from Jealous
Of a Rivall's fortune, will crown his Love
With the good Knight's allowance of Clarinda's.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Hey day! all this buſle for a Willow Garland?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.p: If I muſt wear one, I will have added to't, both Groom and Bride's free and grateful acknowledgment, 'tis I unite them, and that to my pretended skill i'th' ſtars they owe their happineſs.
But who have we here? a new Conſulter?

sp.speaker: Bern
sp.l: An old one, I think.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Nay! We have more Chamber-practice then half the Lawyers in town; yet the devil a fee or feeling I get amongſt all our Clients:

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: This 'tis to ſerve a Generous Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p:
That does all for God-a-mercy, and the credit of doing it,
and cries a good deed carries its own reward along with it.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.p: Peace Preacher.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: Prythee what old Don is it?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.p: 'Tis a Monſieur, Man, has ſerv'd Sr Chriſtopher Credulous ever ſince his travels, he brought him a young fellow out of France with him, Monſieur La-gripe.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: A griping Sir, I warrant him,

sp.speaker: La-gr.
sp.l: Ah Monſieur de Aſtrologue.

sp.speaker: Sh. and Raw.
sp.l: Monſieur La-gripe.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: For Clarinda ſake, Clarinda our common Miſtreſs they ſmile.—dat is te Miſtres of us bote, ſerve for Love, ſerve for Money, for de Vages, Vat you call? it is all one, it iſe ſerve ſtill.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Has he not made it good?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Not good Engliſh, Sir.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Good Pedlar's French, Sir, and that's better for Variety.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Hear out his ſtorie.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: If I didde dare praye you of one faueur.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: What is it?

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: Very ſmall petite choſe, de no tingue.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: But what? I'le do any thing for thee, honeſt Monſieur,

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: Doe that den, I pray youe.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: That? what? I will and I can.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: Oh if you can; Vraiment it is no if's nor Ans.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Can I unleſs you tell me what you would have done?

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: No laugh at me, one poor old French man, pourquoy demande Vat, Ven you can as Vell tell, Var I ſay have done, as you can doe.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: May be ſo too.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: Vat you tinke me no knoe Vat you can doe? as if me no hear my old Maſter, my fellow Beatrige, and all te town beſides talk of you.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: But doe you hear I can know another's
Thought without his intimation?

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: I hear no intimation; Vat I hear, I know;
I no know dat.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Can a man deuine your meaning?

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p:
Devine my mean? you look in my viſage, you knoe
all, and yet I tell you notingue; you be no man to tell long ſtorie to; derefore no aske me Vat I uould, but doe vat I uoude.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I ſhall be hard enough for thee yet, old fox.
'Tis not with thee Monſieur I would diſſemble
My knowledge or my power; ſuch palliations
Of an unkind repulſe derogate—

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: Ah Monſieur! no hard vords, I pray you, Pallaſhons! de gros cat! Vat te divell is dat to me? Plain Engliſh is hard enough for me, I promiſe you. How you think I entend doſe ſayings? I have no devell but thirty years in dis Contry.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.p: Why, plainly thus then; I know what brought thee hither, and what thou wilt requeſt of me!

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: Oh, oh! look you dere den! me know very vell vat I ſay, I varrant's you; me no drunk.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.p: But ſoft: though I doe, I muſt not tell, nor uſe that knowledge for ought thou ſeekſt of me, the reaſon's this; I can do but one thing for thee at a time: if then to read or tell thy thought be it, never expect me ſerviceable to the procurement of that wiſh, that is a ſecond act, my hands are tied from at this t me.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: Nay den, me tell you.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Diſcover his wiſh to day, and help him to't to morrow. Where were you now Sir, if my Monſieur ſhould come upon you thus?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.p: A French man, and ſtay till to morrow? That's a thing was never heard of; delayes are not for them, they nere got by 'em.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: I be quite tired out uitte ſervice here in England, tired as one Jade, uerefore me have a great mind, to return to me own poor Contry agen, to lay it my bones at home, and te money me ſcrape up in dis; but begare it be one uery Long Journie, and uery dangerous too, danger upon te Sea, danger upon te Eaiſe; I be rob here or dere, no like dat uery uell, be kill'd, aſſaſſined, or drown in te ſea, begare like that uery uorſe: an dat is te reaſon I come pray you, to ſecure my perſonne, and my purſe, by ſome Enſhantement, I no know how, to tranſporte me at my home in one minute.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Oh Excellent Monſieur!

sp.speaker: End.
sp.p: You ſee by this what they think of me Sh. and Raw. whiſper. abroad. Pray heaven I don't take my ſelf at laſt for that I'm given out for, theſe are ſtrong temptations.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.p: And ſo become a wiſe man by fancying Sh. whiſpers with End. your ſelf one;

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.p: As, they ſay, they do Witches, by ſtrongly conceiting themſelves Witches,

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: I ha' skill enough for this feat without my Maſter's meddling in't, I'le convey thee into France.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.p: Prepare your ſelf againſt night, Monſieur for the Journey; Shift ſhall be readie too with what on our part is neceſſarie.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: I no dare truſte him, littell Coquin delny,
Play me ſome tricque or toder.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: No, no; his fellow Rawman there ſhall go
Along too, and ſee fair play. Let's leave 'em
To their work, and laugh at him a little.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: Miſter ſirrah, doe for me vat muſt be done
Fair and honeſt, your Maſter command;
You meddell in dis buſineſs de juggle too den.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: I'm half a Conjurer, ſince I ſerve him,
And yet I came to him but a Rawman t'other day.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: An he parboil your Coxecombe?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Pickle him a little in the black art, or ſo.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: Indeed? but is he ſo knoing, tey ſay?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Hear him talk of a Man
You'ld think he had bin in his belley,
He's ſo acquainted with every cranie of his heart.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: I no pleaſe me ſerve ſouche Maſter, a
Valet no paſs vell his time vit him.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Why? I have a good place on't.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: Place Vat you Vill, I no be bound ſerve one,
I no dare tell lye to ſometime.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: 'Tis ſomewhat a hard caſe, but it muſt be ſo here.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: If he ſend you of arrant, you ſtay a great vile, you no dare make excuſe; extend what I mean by excuſe? Sh. Ouy, ouy.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p:
I meet a friend by de Vay, I ſtay trink vit him a littell, one, two, three, fower howers (dat I learn in England tough)
one no dare tell ſouche Man, Monſieur, make me ſtay for one anſwer, yet Company come, no can write; or I cherche him in ſeverall places, 'fore I find: call at te tailleur's, ſee your ſute be make. An oder Man ſatisfie vit one of teſe, he know te contrary, he no ſatisfie vit 'tis nor notingue elſe, Vich de fear of put away, or receive diſtribution—you underſtand.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Ouy, ouy. La-g. on te head and ſhoulders put in one Mouſe; you no dare go to de Cabaret, Ven he at the Comedie, nor make good ſhear vit the Maids at home; no, nor goe to one bordell, Vile he at an oder.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Unleſs I knew he had ſuch great buſineſs in hand, as leſt him no leaſure to think of me.

sp.speaker: La-g
sp.p: And ſo I ſay agen, me rader beg, ſteal, doe any hardeſhip, ten ſerve one Maſter, I no dare tell lye to.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: This neceſſity of ſpeaking truth was ſomething hard to me too at firſt, but I was forc'd to betake my ſelf to't, and uſe, thou know'ſt, brings perfectneſs.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: Dou dare not, (tough among diſcreet bodies, dat vill keep Counſell) tell tales of him, or recount his ſecrets.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: No marry, dare I not; ſecrecy is that he chiefly requires of a ſervant.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: And vat is vorſe, if looſing his money, or ſome todre ill humeur, make him Colerick, an he Vell-come you home Vit Coups de pied.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: How now? La-g. or one good ſoufflet, or two.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Nay, nay; one's enough.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: Dere is no complaining, 'tis ſo mouche for you; and fear of more, you muſt bite your tongue, and ſwallow your choler, as they ſay in my Countrie.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: I, ſure enough.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: Vat Conſolation 'tis Monſieur Sift to ſwear and curſe at ſouche Maſter? my bones no ake more▪ Ven mong my Camarades, I can give him heartily to all te divels.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: I ha' got the length of his foot now,
And ſeldome am in this predicament.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Beſides he's good condition'd.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: Good or bad, one fair morning I vould
Pack up my nawles and be gone for all date.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Would not he know my mind, and ſo prevent me, had I any ſuch intention?

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: Vhy dere's todre ting I no ſpeak. You no dare runne vaye neider, no dare tink of it, nor find one oder Maſter in ſecret, if dis fall out vis you.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: 'Tis a common trick indeed of ſervants, that grow wearie of one Maſter, to have another in reſerve:

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Like Women who (for fear of wanting) provide a ſecond husband, before the firſt be dead; but that Providence We are debarr'd of too.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: An odre incommodite I no reckon, an te gran incommodite of all; how you pick up money in 'tis ſervice? a Man gett no more but bare vages? Pewh! it is no Vorth Vile, I ſhould be ſorrie to rob any bodie; begarre I make conſcience of dat: but if Largent go torow my hands, 'tis like meal, flower, Vat you call? ſometing ſtick, ſtick ſtill to de fingers.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Ah ſirrah! you go ſnip i' your Maſter's money then, you take toll, you black Miller, you, you more Vnavoidable thief then his Worſhip's tailour.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: You make a Conſcience of robbing, but you filch, you pilfer▪ you purloin unmercifully.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Thou haſt a fine time on't, that we want; and Enjoy'ſt a revenue, We dare not pretend to.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: My Maſter hates theft beyond imagination, and I think that for a Teſter (mercileſs as he is) he could find in's heart to have us taught to dance in a rope.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: I'm ſorrie for thy ſake thou cameſt to him, ſince thou art given that way; for finding it out (as doubtleſs he would by thy looks) he may very well tell thy Maſter.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: Tell my Maſter? oh me loſt, me loſt! vat I doe?

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Why, thy worſt is but to be hang'd.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: And is no dat bad enofe, my friend?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Perhaps thou mayſt be quit for a ſinging
Or ſo: thou canſt read?

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p:
Yes, yes; if he did need to know one name, to tell one's fortune, or doings, denne me attrappe him very vell, for La-gripe no me true name, me take datte, becauſe me Vould gripe vell good moneys here, and leave my own name Vit my Countrie,
for one blow I doe, how you call? a ting, Vich make me leave France; I no come into England, no, vitte Sr Chriſtophore elſe.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Though he could not; yet knowing our names y'have told all this to, he cannot when his liſt but know what has paſt amongſt us.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: How could he elſe diſcover to the full what concerns him, or me: thou ſhalt find no eaſe on that ſide neither.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: No, no; We'l keep his fears up to the height ſtill.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: Dat very true too; but my goode Sift, if it be poſſible, make he no tell.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Haſt thou filcht ſoundly?

sp.speaker: La g.
sp.l: Not mouch at a time.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: But often?

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: Teuenty or tirty a monts, but littell, littell everie one, dat he no find: you call at Seſſions Pettie Larcenie.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Then a whipping perchance may ſerve.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: A Vippingue? vhy many littell tefts no amount to a great teft.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: But they make thee a great thief;
And may mount thee to the gallows.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Saving that, I know no way but one.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: Oh goode Sifte, tell dat toder vay, I take dat rader.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: My Maſter's head's ſo full now thou mayeſt get out of town, and he ne're mind thee; go thy wayes then preſently, and pack up; if the old Knight ſhould hear of thy pranks, he'l not ſend into France after thee.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: If I be dere once, I no care dis for him; but I no dere yet.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Fetch but thy things, We'l ſet thee going.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: 'Tis great vay.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Were't further yet, We'l have thee thither to day.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: But thou muſt be well provided againſt the cold; there blow certain winds at Sea, thou wilt not like.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: Vat? at Mid-ſummer?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: I; as hot as 'tis at Land.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: That's the onely inconvenience of the Journey,
But thou'lt be over in a hower or two.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p:
I feare no Vindes nor Veader; I feare my Maſter
more, and dine too: but how I be carried?

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: At eaſe, as e're thou wert.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Meet me in thy Maſter's garden,
I'le be there preſently.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: Let it be no long preſent, nor no perhaps.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Be you but ready.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: If you no come, me very angry.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: I will come, I tell thee.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: He's o'th' houſe of the Credulous too:

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: I'th' Lime alreadie, boy.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: There let him flutter.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: BEllamy, I have been ſeeking you;

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Me Sir? I have my wiſh if I can ſerve you;
Lay your commands upon me.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: A Courteous Gentleman, and a handſome one!
Who would take him for a Pick-pocket now
By his looks? but fronti nulla ſides.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: What means he talking to himſelf to eye
Me thus? has he already diſcover'd
Our Love, the art We us'd to hide it too?
Cruel fates! ſo ſpeedie in your malice?

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.p: Fooliſh man that I am! I can ſcarce find in my aſide. heart to ſpeak to him now, I would not ſhame him quite; I muſt diſſemble, and pretend that ſome other way my ring is faln into his hands. To be brief with you, there is a certain Jewel wanting, a ſmall toy a ring, or ſo, and I am told, you have it.

sp.speaker: Bell
sp.l: How ſoon are all my hopes blaſted?

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: How he is ſtruck? his very Countenance pleads guilty.

sp.speaker: Bellamy.
sp.l: This the fair ſucceſs I flatter'd my ſelf with?

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: I do not ſay, Bellamy, you are faulty,
But the party you have it by.

sp.speaker: Bellamy,
sp.l: With what obſtinacy are we perſecuted?

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Trouble not your ſelf; 'tis the hand alone
You have it from is guilty;
You are otherwiſe juſtifiable enough.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I have the Diamond, Sir, I can't denie't,
And here am ready to reſtore it you.
Y'are prepoſſeſt, I fear, by ſome, with a
Falſe ſtory of the meanes I wrought it by;
But if truth may be heard, as ſure it ought
In ſpight of their inſinuations, the guilt
Is all mine, I have no Complices;
Rather die, then Peach Clarinda.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: I ſeek to excuſe him, and he fondly accuſes himſelf

sp.speaker: Bellamy.
sp.l: Let's clear her, all we can. I tell you, Sir,
What e're y'have heard, I am in all the fault,
Nor do I plead ought to attenuate.—

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: How ſtrangely does a guilty Conſcience wring him?
I palliate his fault, he exaggerates it.

sp.speaker: Bellamy.
sp.l: I ſeek not therefore to attenuate
A Crime, which when I firſt deſign'd.—

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.p: I am not ignorant of the Fact, Bellamy, ſet no miſſeeming gloſs upon't, I know the naked truth; but though I do, the knowledge of it ſhall not hurt you.

sp.speaker: Bellamy.
sp.l: There's no diſſembling with you then;
Plain-dealing, now is beſt I do confeſs.—

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.p: Oh, Do you ſo, Sir? Do you ſo? but look to't another time; for, Confeſs and be hang'd, D'ee mark? that's the Word.

sp.speaker: Bellamy.
sp.l: I do confeſs my furtive actions then,
My Stealth, my Clandeſtine approaches, and
The ſurprizal▪ of a Jewel, which I ſee,
I am in your opinion too
Unworthy of: 'tis true, I am too bold,
Nor can I ought in my defence now plead:
'Twas the predominance of ſome ill Star
I'le ſay, ſince it brings your diſpleaſure,
Forc'd me to what is paſt.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: I am not ſo ſevere a Judge neither;
I have been young my ſelf, and can not now
Be ignorant what youth is ſubject to;
And ſome occaſions ſeem to force our will,
Such powerful allurements they tempt it with.

sp.speaker: Bellamy.
sp.l: Yet though my indeſert ſeem to forbid
All hope of pardon, by your own goodneſs
Sir, I dare Conjure you.—

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Yes, yes, I am merciful, I tell you,
And can excuſe: having my Ring too, I
May hold my peace; 'tis an ordinary courſe
When a Man has his Good's again,
To wave the proſecution.

sp.speaker: Bellamy.
sp.l: I muſt not loſe this opportunity,
I ſhall not take him in the mood agen.
Since you with ſo much goodneſs can excuſe,
Be good ſtill, Sir, and to juſtifie me
Thoroughly, Authorize my crime,
And give Clarinda leave
To crown my paſſion with approv'd conſent;
Permit me, Sir, to Marry her.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Marry my Daughter? for what acquaintance troe?
The Man's mad ſure, or I am mad my ſelf;
He thinks me ſo at leaſt, he'd ne're talk thus elſe.

sp.speaker: Bellamy.
sp.l: Though my meanes are ſmall, I have a heart yet,
No frowning fortune, no adverſity
Can bring under; and am of a Family
From which ſome richer ones may receive no
Small luſt • e; look on me then, Sir, with eyes
And you will ſee no cauſe to ſcorn th' alliance.

sp.speaker: S Chr.
sp.l: I • cannot be in earneſt ſure all this,
Or with the leaſt thought of perſwading me:
Finding ſome danger in the Trade of Cut-Purſe,
He's now fall'n to, he will grow wiſe, and take
I • p • a • my coſt for which purpoſe he muſt
Needs marry my Daughter forſooth; this is
One of the fineſt Fooles.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: He's ſomething long-a-conſidering on't.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.p: Let him ſteal, let him pick, let him cut, as many aſide Purſes, or Pockets, as he pleaſe; let him be hang'd too, and he will, he'l not diſoblige me in't at all: but for Marrying my Daughter, Pardonnez moy, Monſieur; well, Bellamy, I promiſe you, what ever you have ſaid.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Your Daughter, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Secreſie, Sir, ſecreſie; I'le keep your Counſel,
And that's no ſmall curteſie, I hope.

sp.speaker: Bellamy.
sp.l: Was ever Man in ſuch a maze as I?
His fav'rable conſtruction of what's paſt,
Seemes to invite a full Confeſſion:
And when he knowes my paſſion for his daughter,
He promiſes ſecreſie, and cries, he
Will keep Counſel. 'Tis the croſſeſt this of
All my croſs fortunes.
This importune Woman is another;
Let's give her the ſlip.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Stay, Bellamy, and be civil at leaſt,
If you cannot be kind.
Is that heart then I have ſo long thought mine
An others Captive now?
Inconſtancie and breach of Faith, it ſeemes,
Are pleaſing grown to him, ſo often Vow'd
The Vertues contrary; the change it ſelf
Is ordinary enough, nor am I
The firſt forſaken ſhe.
But yet to ſhun a ſight, you once
Swore, pleas'd you 'bove all others, is too ſtrong
An effect, methinks, of a new paſſion;
'Tis paſt indifferencie this, even to ſcorn;
You might remember that you lov'd me once.

sp.speaker: Bellamy.
sp.l: Say, I eſteem'd you, Madam: Love
In the reſpects I paied you, had leaſt ſhare;
My obligations t'ee were great,
And ſo I ſtrove to bear a mind
Full of reſentments for your noble favours,
A grateful, though not paſſionate heart.
But 'tis no time for ſuch diſguiſes now,
'Tis fit each action wear it's proper name,
Own it's true motive;
Lay your credulity then aſide,
For love has bound me in thoſe fetters now,
Muſt ne're be cut but with my thread of life.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: With what art this ſtudied declaration
In ſuch ambiguous tearmes is couch'd,
It may be made for me as for another?
He neither nam'd Celia, nor Clarinda.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: 'Tis as plain though, he meanes her, as if he had.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: But you are ſo credulous, as he tells you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: This night I waited on you by your own appoinment, what my reception was, you cannot have forgot, th' affront was to premeditate; you could not afford me one ſerious word, no, nor your eare a minute: think not the return I make you ſtrange then, nor wonder, that I ſhun you now, as you did me; t'was your command I ſhould, and I obey you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: He's in love w'ee, you will believe it ſtill?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: He does, he does love me, I tell thee, ſtrangely.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: 'Tis ſtrangely indeed, if he loves at all;
And as ſtrangely he ſhewes it.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: 'Tis but a triall when he ſlights me thus,
'Tis then he loves me paſſionately;
This ſenſe of my odd carriage in the night
Is moſt becoming, and I take it kindly:
We're indifferent to him, he would mind it leſs,
Loving me, as he does, he muſt reſent it thus.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: With an other, you ſee, he does himſelf
Confeſs he is in love.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: For tryal ſtill, I tell thee, he affects
Inconſtancie, as he does ſcorn;
And for revenge perphaps a little too
He ſeekes to vex me thus; all's diſſembling,
Nor does he ſtrive to make me Jealous, but
To diſcover at full the kindneſs I have
For him; 'tis that, I ſee, he aimes at,
Endimion told me 'twould be ſo.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: Nay, for him, he's a cheat, I'm ſure, what ever the other be.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: He has abus'd you, Madam, all-a-long,
His predictions are meere fictions,
Meere impoſtures.
sp.p: You might (but that you were before you ſpoke with him, ſtrangely perſwaded of his skill) have ſeen it in his whole proceeding.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: He but deludes you with vain hopes,
Bellamy does forſake you.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Can you be ignorant he adores Clarinda?

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Gratian aſſures you of it too.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I truſt not to what Gratian ſayes; he has
Caſt off all thoughts of friendſhip, and without
The leaſt regard to Bellamy, or his love,
Is hourely troubling me with his own,
You ſee he is.
I give no credit to a Rivall's ſtory.
For whatſo're of Bellamy he ſayes,
I've cauſe to fear, but reaſon ſtill to doubt.

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: Rather believe him, Madam; for you'l find
Gratians Story is a true one. His love
Though violent, can hear ſome reaſon yet,
And keep within the bounds of honour; think
Not then, he ſeekes by treachery to win you,
By baſe ſuggeſtions to ſupplant his friend.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: While I thought him worthy of you,
Or could on any grounds believe him yours,
What did I, Madam, or what ſaid I, to
Croſs your fair affections?
I was all friend then, mov'd not one ſtep
Out of my Confident's path, for him was
All I ſpoke, my own cauſe I pleaded but
With ſilence, allow'd it not the leaſt complaint,
But what was fair from reaching him, or you;
Or if ſome time a ſudden ſigh broke through
The care I us'd to keep 'em in, how ſoon
Like to ſome bluſht-at, or unlawful iſſue,
Did I diſavow it, nay, lay it to
Another? but the concealment
Of my ſufferings and his injuries t'ee,
Would not a kindneſs now to Bellamy prove
That falſe Bellamy?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: How loth am I yet to believe him ſuch?
Can he be falſe to Celia, that thought ſo
Well of him? She that ſo truely lov'd him?

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: 'Tis ſtrange a heart once yours, ſhould ever own
An other Conqueror: but he is falſe, falſe
To the faireſt Celia, falſe, as miſerable
In this Exchange.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Bellamy forſakes me?

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Perhaps 'tis with regret, a ſharp remorſe
Perhaps poyſons all the ſweets he leaves you Sir
Yet he forſakes you ſtill; and with his own
Conſent I tell you ſo.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: And 'tis Clarinda
Robs me of this beloved Perjurer?

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: But now We left him at Sr Chriſtopher's.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: And leaſt we ſhould miſtake him any longer
Gratian, (cryed he to me, as he went in)
I know your paſsion, and ceaſe t'oppoſe it,
I quit all claim to Celia; for if love
Have happineſs for me, 'tis in Clarinda's Armes.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: May I believe all this?

sp.speaker: Ler.
sp.l: A greater truth ne're challeng'd your beliefe.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Alas! he never left the town, but lurk'd
At my houſe for private meetings
With Clarinda, whom he ſaw night by night.
A truth though, no Intereſt of my own
Had e're extorted, did not yours claim it,
And his allowance Manumize the ſecret.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: No more; my doubt is over, and the miſt
Love caſt before my eyes thus vaniſht, more
Hateſul, as more hated does he appear,
Then ever he ſeem'd lovely, nor was my
Affection ever half ſo ſtrong, as now
My anger is▪ Gratian, do you love me?

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Oh Madam!

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: How can I ever believe Man agen,
When Bellamy is falſe? yet follow me,
If your affection be ſincere, as you
Proteſt; Celia is yours; but bring me to
Clarinda's, and make my own eyes witneſs
His crime, that I may do you Juſtice there
Before his face; ſerve my anger ſo farre,
And ſecond the revenge I do intend,
That he may ſee himſelf forſaken, as he
Forſakes, and there (if I may have my wiſh)
Shall he repent his perjurie,

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: That I believe too.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Yet all in vain.
Loſt to all hopes of e're recovering
What he ſo baſely does renounce; there let
Him pine to find me in another's arms,
And without hopes of either Miſtreſs, ſee
Clarinda ſcorn him, as he now does me.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: A fine humour this, Luce;

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: An 'twould hold.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Oh, it muſt hold.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Whether Love will or no?

div.head: SCENE II. Sir Chriſtopher's Garden.
div.stage: Enter La-gripe in a travelling habit.

sp.p: A Dieu, London, adieu; I goe ſee my own naturall Contree agen: an France be ne're ſo bad, or England ſo good, better be alive dere, den hang here.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: How now, art readie?

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: Dou ſeeſt, te good Capotte, Vit my bottes ala Candalle

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: 'Tis well, 'tis well, thou haſt clad thy ſelf warm; the Journey's ſomething bleak, as I told thee.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: I putt tis hood over my face, for fear te cold, and ſome todre ting make me looſe my noſe quite.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: I think indeed 'tis ſomething looſe ſet on.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Zymar, Haly, Behemoth, Albenzera.
Get into this Circle.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: Vat dou Mumble, mumble in te teeths?
Say te divells Pater noſter, I tinke.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Words of art, words of art: but 'tis done alreadie. Thou muſt be hoodwink'd now.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: Pourquoy?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: There are reaſons for't, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: Your Jockeys, I hear ſay, ride temſelf blind,
But for uate I be make blinde, before I ride.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: With the great light, and that prodigious height thou wilt be mounted to thy eyes would be dazled, and thou giddily come tumbling down.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Who knows too how near thou mayeſt come to the Sun, thy Lids would not ſave 'em from ſcorching then, nor the diſtillations ſtill overflowing quench the fire.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: That brinie dew would add more furie to't.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Then thy noſe would melt off indeed,
But this muffler ſaves all.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: Indeed me have grand diſtraction, to ſee all te Vorld at one time, I can no hinder my ſelf from be peeping in every corner; I tinkue I mind me buſineſs better, and ſee notinge, dereſore blinde me, I am content: but how I ride? Vat be carried on? uere dat?

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: I need but whiſtle, and 'tis here.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: Is it a ſaddel horſe, or one Coche?

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: No, no; a pad-nag.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: A bad nag? begare me uill have a good nag, or no goe at all your Vay.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Thou ſhalt have a good one;
I ſay, a pad-nag, a fine gentle pacer.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: Oh crie you mercie, Vnderſtand now; my Maſter ride ſouche one himſelf, 'tis very eaſie for us olde Men: but Vho be my guide? Vat if I looſe my vaie? it very like; for I no travell dat rode before.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: There's a queſtion indeed! thou ſhalt have a little Orengetawny devill to lacquey by thy ſide.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: A divell lacquey? I no hear of ſouch before.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Why, half the lacqueys about the town are devils, Man, and in thy Country they are ten times worſe.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: Dat's true indeed; but I always hear ſay, te divell uery proud, and tink he no take ſo mean place.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Some of 'em I grant are above it, but there are enow to ſupply all places, and he will put on any ſhape, rather then not make one.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Which is to play at ſmall game, rather then ſit out.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Shall I tell thee? there are devils of all functions and qualities, trades and callings whatſoever.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Alas, the Myſterie of every trade is knavery,
And that leads directly to him.
There are Sergeants, and Bailiff-divils.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: And divilliſhly are they us'd, when they meddle with a guard-man, or any of the Boulley Rocks indeed.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Some neat, dapper, well-handed fiends are cut out into Barbers, Tire-women, and Valets de chambre;

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Of which there come ſuch ſhoules out of thy Country:

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Your nimbler handed ones make Tailors, and Weavers.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Thieving devils: he devils, and ſhe devils.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: Vat Voman divels?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Oh ſans nombre: and they make cuckolds.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: Te divell Cuckold too?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: How ſhould he come by his horns elſe?

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: And for more fiendly variety, there are ſage devils, and mad devils; hectoring devils, and cowardly devills; quaking devils—

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: Yes, in froſt and ſnoe; I have bin ſuch one my ſelf, before I come to good Angliſh Cole fires.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: But theſe quake now, at Midſummer.

sp.speaker: La-g.
