sp.l: Begare trowe 'em in te river, and make
Quake for ſome ting.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Come, thou ſtay'ſt a deviliſh while here,
'Tis time thou wert goue.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: There are water-devils too; but thoſe we call dippers.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Rumpers and thumpers. Raw. Zealous and impious.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Preciſe and prophane.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Merry devils, and very devils, commonly known by the name of Phanaticks.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: But thine's come; get up, get up.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: Oh undoe, undoe; I ſee if mine be a horned divell; your men Cuckolds hide teir horn ſo, you no ſee a great manies; I long to ſee how te divell wear his.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: 'Twere worth ſeeing indeed: but let everie Cuckold wear his own horns, and as he pleas himſelf: this is a batchelor devil; one though that having no apes to lead in hell, comes to lead a baboon into France.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: Vat's dat? Vat's dat? I have great Curioſity
To look him in face.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: Take heed, 'tis dangerous; he has a more dreadful countenance ten times then thy old Maſter.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: Gare, and he one I no mouche care for ſee now.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Then ſee him, and ſpare not.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: I look him out of Countenance, Ven I am dere.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Come, get up, get up.

div.stage: horſes him on a rail or hedge with a cuſhion under him.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: Vell Monſieur te divell, do not quitte me, Ven you get me in one ſtrange place, bring me ſafe in my countree, and den I can doe vell enof vit oute you.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Ne're fear him, he'l not leave thee ſo,
Thou art too good a bit for him.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: For Vat you tie ſo hard, Maſter Sift?
is it you, or te divell?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: He's afraid thou wilt ſlip from him.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: No, no, I varrant's you, if he no run
Way from me.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: If he does, ride after him;
Thou art damnably well mounted.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Is't eaſier now?

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: I, I, now 'tis vell; but vho vntie me, Vhen I come home, I can no doe't my ſelf, I no ſee.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: It ſhall be done to thy hand,
When thou art at thy Journey's end.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: O Sift, Sift, I forgot; Vill tis Jade carrie in crouper, Vat you call in England? double, double, carrie double?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Why doe'ſt ask?

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: I take my felloe Beatrige along Vit me, ſhe ride behind; very good companie for te divell, and for me too, very good in te vay.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Yes, too good for thee, old Jew; what ride double? aſide. to him. No, no, ride poſt to th' devil, the old ſaying is; I could have order'd it ſo, ſhe might have gone too; but 'tis too late now, and thou muſt take the Journey ſingle, as thou art.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: Vell, vell, 'tis no matter; I get an odre in France.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: By this token know thou art within ken; a doleful Voyce thou ſhalt firſt hear; at thy arrival, wrangling or confuſed talk, then lowder Lamentations; but fare thee well, ſet forward.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Commend us to our friends in Paris.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: Yes, yes; dat I vill.
sp.stage: in a hollow tone as from a farre

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Adieu, Monſieur La-gripe, adieu.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Adieu, La-gripe, adieu; with what ſpeed thou flyeſt?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: How he cleaves the air? he's gone, hes gone;
I can ſcarce diſcern him now.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p:
I doe perceive I fly very faſt indeed, for now I hardly
hear teir Voice, my Eares take but te laſt Accents, as of one very remote.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: A right Frenchman! bread in's pocket;

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Where's the Cheeze?

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Oh, that's at his Toes to haut-gouſt.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Which he calls refining.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: I be in France preſant, I drink good Claret Vine, pure, pure; no mingle mangle, red and white, as here in England.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Do, fuddle thy Noſe, and if they pick thy pocket I'le pay the reckoning.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: I take Sift for one little Quenave,
And he prove honeſt little Fellow.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Yes, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: Rawman too, very well vers'd, experienc'd—

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: In thy Pockets.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: Te beaſt tey ſet me upon, go as eaſie
Too, as no ſtir at all.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: If it does, they are miſtaken.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: No ſhake, ſhake me; need no ſpur neider.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: The ill manner'd Jade would hardly anſwer to't.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: I be as ſtill as in me Bed, ſure I very good Horſeman.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: For the Woodden-Horſe.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: I no looſe in te Saddel.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Nor in the Hilts?

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: 'Tis very holeſome air, I grow very hungry.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: You ſtuff'd your Pockets, as if y'had known you ſhould—

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.l: But Vat Vind tis? ſtinking Vind too,
sp.stage: R. Biows in's face with a pair of bellows.
sp.l: Tell me dere blow,
One Vind very cold, and ſo 'tis indeed,
I ſee he know all tings in te vay, as
He go it himſelf.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: An other gale, an other gale.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: Te Vind turn; ſure my Beard freeze wit tis blow, blow. I fear my Noſe too for all tis good Capotte, I no dare feel how tis neider.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: There's company come in to th' garden,
We muſt away.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: Jog on, jog on good Antiquity.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Y'are almoſt at your Journeyes end.

div.stage: Enter Bellamy, Clarinda with a thin hood on.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Diſcover'd already? So ſoon betray'd
Unto my Fathers knowledge?
What hard fates, Bellamy, attend our Loves?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: You ſtand yet▪ blameleſs in your Father's eye;
I wholly drew the Crime upon my ſelf,
And rather choſe to paſs for a ſuborner,
Then you ſhould forward ſeem, in the diſpoſal
Of that he claimes it is his right to give.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: No, no; We do but fool our ſelves with hopes,
There is no ground left for that ſelf-flatterie.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Soon as he tax'd me with the Ring, I rendred it,
That precious pledge of thy unmatch'd affection:
Let not thy griefe precede our miſery though,
He neither ſhew'd, nor threatned any rigour,
He ſpoke but in his wonted tone, rather
Amaz'd then angry, and us'd me (truſt me
Sweet he did) with much mildneſs ſtill; and ſeem'd
(By arguing the buſineſs with himſelf)
Something irreſolute what courſe to take;
And I dare hope, if from thy ſelf he hear
Thou doeſt affect me, it may incline him
To allow thy choice.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I that will doe't, I'le dry my eyes agen,
We'l nere be wretched ſure, when ſpeaking truth
Can make us happy. If this may win him,
Clarinda's yours; once more I tell you ſo.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: VVhat grief is proofe againſt this joy?
Or what miſery has a name, which theſe words
Clarinda's mine, would not charm into happineſs?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I'm yours for ever, or no Man's; he that can debarr me of this felicitie, ſhall not add to my affliction, being an others.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Such bliſs in ſilence ſtill is beſt receiv'd,
I want words to give full thankes.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: I underſtand ſome noiſe of Tongues, ſome People talking a great way of, ſure I ride over ſome great City; Is it Canterbury? no, no, I hope I be paſs te Seas.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: How now? Is there any body come in?

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.p: Oh yes, Sir Chriſtopher, and the Aſtrologer forſooth; he's no body without him now: he was wont to dote upon wealth, and then our Houſe was nothing but Aldermen, and Citizens, that write themſelves Eſquire, and Country Knights, that never came to Town, but for a new Purchaſe: but that fit's over now, and learning is his bable.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: They interupt us too ſoon, I would not
Have him ſee you yet, Endimion being with him too.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Can I not ſlip out?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: No, I know his walkes, he uſes at his entrance to take that, ſhould now lead you out; but ſtep aſide, ith' cloſe walk he'l not diſcover you: and there, if boldly ſpeaking in our cauſe may carry it, you'l hear me plead for you as you were here your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: You are all goodneſs, Madam.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: Good Devil, look to me, if I be at Sea, for I can no ſwimme.

div.stage: To them Sr Chriſtopher Credulous, Endimion, Bernard, Shift.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: A moſt delicious garden this!

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: 'Tis my Whore, Sir, 'tis my Whore;
Here I delight, and conſume my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: That's e'en a Whore's trick indeed

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Here, Clarinda, here's thy Ring again.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Muſt I endure that object in my Eye?

div.stage: To B. pulling down her hood. Turning it up.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.p: What ſo coy, Miſtreſs? Will you not parley unveil'd?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: The Sun's too hot, Sir, I never walk in't
Without my Hood, I ſhall be tann'd.

sp.speaker: S• Chr.
sp.p: And you be, and you be, 'tis but one Takes it quite off. lick more, you have that in your Cloſet, I know, can fetch it off again; here Gentlewoman, Throwes it Beat. that belongs to your care.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.p: I long'd to ſee how Clarinda did behave her To Bern. ſelf after all theſe odd accidents, and how ſhe'ld look upon me.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: She's too much diſcompos'd;

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: She is, and I too well reveng'd; I pity her.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.p: 'Tis not a civil wellcome this, of a perſon thou art ſo lately, and ſo much oblig'd too; 'tis to him thou art engag'd for the recovery of thy Ring; I thought thou would'ſt have ſlown into his armes, had help'd thee to't again, thou wert ſo loſt for want of it.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Gladly into his, that had it.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.p: Your Father, Madam, is pleas'd to name an Obligation So ſlight, I dare not think it one.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: 'Tis one indeed, ſhe con's you little thanks.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: But if kind Heaven proſper what I intend,
A ſolid and important ſervice ſhall
Prove the Zeal I have to pleaſe you.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: You have already, Sir, oblig'd me, more
Then I can thank you for.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: By te different noiſes I find I paſs from place to place; and now I tink I am at Callais; gare te Steeples, if I be.

div.stage: To them Gratian, Lewis, Celia, Fannie, Luce,

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Here's more Company, What Ladie's that? or what would ſhe?
She lookes with an earneſt, and a buſie face.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: With an angry one, methinks.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: 'Tis a pretty little angry Rogue,
Would I had the pleaſing of her.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: You pleaſe her? pleaſe me? and hear the Lady.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Wonder not Sir, at ſo abrupt a viſit,
I come for Juſtice t'ee; We are both wrong'd,
Both abus'd by one unconſtant Man; one
That when a thouſand Oathes had made him mine,
Your Daughter has ſtoln from me; nay, ſtart not,
She loves him infinitely; he nere had left
Me for an unkind one, no, no they burn
In mutual flames; and in your houſe, or Garden
Is he now conceal'd, now, this very minute:
Do me reaſon then, and your ſelf Juſtice.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: I wiſh he be here, for I begin to fear,
Finding Clarinda without him.

sp.speaker: La g.
sp.p: Sure tis is te doleful Voice, te lamentation; good ſign, good ſign, I be almoſt come home.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.p: How! a man hidden in my houſe? a plot, a plot; fetch me my rapier there, I'le poak him out of his hole; a plot upon my daughter.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Your daughter's plot upon you rather.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: 'Tis an increaſe of miſerie this, I never fear'd;
She's very handſome; what then? nay, I think
Bellamy did love her once; no matter:
Coming juſt i'th' nick too, when he is here,
Silence my Jealouſie,
I've trouble enough without thee.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Pox of this buſsle, 'twill land our Travellour too ſoon.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: My father, I hope, ſuſpects not me
In any cloſe contrivance—

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.p: Nay, nay, 'tis beſt for you be clear; I will think well o' thee ſo long as I may; but if thou bee'ſt faulty, th haſt loſt a f iend of me: I le rage no higher, till I ſee th'accuſation prov'd.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Poor Clarinda!
With what increaſe of trouble I ſee thine?

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: They are all to pieces now indeed.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: I have a ſoder for em yet.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: I am come home ſure, I hear ſuch confuſed tones, and lamentable voices.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Come, Madam, firſt let's make the garden ſure,
This way—hah! what have we here?
This is a skare-crow—

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: Tis is te very noiſe, Sift tell me of; divell, divell, Vere be you, my Lacquey-divell? untie, untie me.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: What Pageant's this: 'tis La-gripe's dialect.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: 'Tis our Travellour, Sir.
He thinks himſelf in France alreadie.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: A haſty Monſieur indeed; but
'Tis no time for this mirth now: help him down.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: Now I be come, now I be come; never make being got off. Journey vit ſo much eaſe. O my Moder Earth, I muſt kiſs dee for Joy.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.p: Why how now?

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: You be got into my Country too? but eaſe me of one ſcruple, how you come? he lend you one pad-nag too? vat co▪lour your Vorſhip's divell? mine Orenge-tawny, dat his colour • of old, you know: I dare ſwear now my Maſter's be one aſide. horned fiend and dat I fear is horn to horn.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: He's mad ſure; ſee where thou art, in London,
In my garden; ſee thy young Miſtreſs too, Beatrix.—

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: Begare I be ſo indeed. I be baſe beſheat, ſtares about him gets up, ſearches his pockets. my purſe gone into France, or ſome Vere elſe ah dou dog-rogue Sift, I have thee by the ears preſent.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: If the devil pick thy pocket, can I help it?

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: This is not the conceal'd Lover, you mean, Madam;
'Tis a diſguiz'd one rather I think this.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I look after no ſuch mouldy ware, Sir.
'T was not this. I hope, you brought me to ſee.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Madam you'l find things yet, as I gave 'em out t'ee.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: If they would ſearch no further now.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: You'l pardon, Sir, my Man's boldneſs, I hope,
That plays the knave thus with yours.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: 'Tis eaſily pardon'd to preſerve your friendſhip:
But to our other buſineſs, our ſerious trouble.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: They turn this way; better ſhew my ſelf,
Then be found ſneaking here.

sp.speaker: Cel
sp.l: Let's ſeek this way.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Seek him no further, Madam, here he is.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Ungrateful, faithleſs Man!

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Hah! Is it he?

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: You perjur'd man, you; have we found you?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Nay, never rail, nor throw at me thoſe undeſerv'd
Reproaches; there is a Ladie here, can vouch my conſtancie.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: What Planet was my Girl born under troe?
I ſeek her Lover, and find a thief, a Pick-pocket.
sp.p: You lay perdu upon ſome new deſign now, there are more Jewels in the houſe, Cabinets unrifled; I pray God there be. Ent. Shift again. This is their trick to a hair; ſlip in th' dusk of the Evening, and when we are all faſt, open the doors to an inundation of Vermin. A pox on this thieve's handſel, I knew there was worſe to follow.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: The Man's beſide himſelf ſure, to wrong a Gentleman thus barbarouſly; though I have reaſon not to think him innocent, yet I dare pawn my life, the baſe guilt you charge him with, is none of's crime. What mean you then by this abuſive Language?

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Alas! he underſtands me, Madam.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Not very well, Sir.
What draws this ſcandalous reproach?
I am no thief, my Enemie, I dare ſwear,
If I have any, will anſwer for me:
My mind is ſet on nobler objects farre,
My name and family free from the leaſt ſtain
Of ſuch ignoble ways; nor have you ought
In all your vaſt poſſeſſions I value,
But your daughter.
'Tis her I love, this year and more ſhe has
Bin Miſtreſs of my life and hopes; the Ring
You tax'd me with, from her hand I newly
Had receiv'd: and if the ſternneſs of a
Father's brow fright not a timerous Maid from
Free diſcoverie of ſuch thoughts, ask her, and
What ſhe makes not good of all my ſtorie,
Repute me lyer in; a name
I would not for your wealth deſerve.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Speak, Clarinda, ſaies he true? do'ſt love him?
Speak boldly, and the truth, what ere it be,
It ſhall be welcome to a father's ear.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Heaven knows I need not bluſh to own it,
And yet I doe, I love him, Sir,
And have done this—

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Nay, nay, then the reſt is plain enough: well
We muſt make the beſt of a bad market.
Endimion your advice.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Nere adviſe with him, he's a mere impoſtor.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Now will he raiſe a new ſtorm.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: Never fear him, his Aſtrologie's well worn out by this.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Let my Ponyard prevent his malice.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: He's born to be hang'd I ſee; becauſe he proves no thief, he'l commit murder.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Celia's yours, I tell you; Endimion
Has no love for Clarinda, I know he has not.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: That aſſurance revives me.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Aſſiſt me now, kind Stars,
To put a period to theſe Lovers paines,
And I'le nere trouble you with an other Suit.

sp.speaker: S Chr.
sp.l: My honour lies at ſtate; what ſhall I doe?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: A fatal chain theſe ſeveral accidents
Are link'd together in, no breaking;
Yeild, yeild to what heaven has decreed, and
Is indeed above halfe done to your hands;
Theſe Lovers were made for one another,
I almoſt told you ſo before, in the
Deſcription of the Man ſhe is ordain'd for;
And ſince one rich in Vertue, not in Land,
Muſt be your Son in Law, where could you better chooſe,
Frank Bellamy is nobly bred, as born:
Give free conſent then to their happineſs,
Let it a fruit of your indulgence to 'em,
And not a forc'd allowance now appear;
That mingled with the joyes we ſhall wiſh them,
Our thankes to you on their behalf may flow.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.p: Well, what muſt be, muſt be; I cannot fail however in following that path Heaven has trac'd out for me. Bellamy, I embrace you as my Son, my Daughter's yours.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: And I for ever to your goodneſs bound.
Oh my Clarinda, now y'are mine indeed.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Is it thus you keep your promiſe, Sir Chriſtopher?
This the Juſtice I look'd for?
My honour ſuffers ſtill.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.p: There was no other ſalve for mine; and Charity begins at home, good Lady; remember that ſtill. As much reaſon, for ought I know, to Marry, as to Chriſten my own Child firſt.

sp.speaker: Cel. to Bell.
sp.l: to goe, follow that miſleading light,
Triumph in thy inconſtancy, and let
Thy now-Miſtreſs taſte of it in time too;
'Tis that, 'tis that will do me right.
Come, Gratian, I'le keep my word with you;
We'l ſtreight to Church.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Moſt willingly; ſweet Lady, I muſt take her i'th' fit.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: 'T would ſoon be over elſe.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Nay, let's not part in anger, Madam; there
Are Weddings towards, We ſhould be friends,
And merry then; Lewis call Gratian back.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: Stay.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: A Woman's anger is ſoon over.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: And a Lad's Love as ſoon out.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Or let it laſt, who cares?

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Or the other, who's the better for't?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: Come, let's hear now, what fine new device you ſtay me for; Oh! you are a ſweet Gentleman, to paſs for an Aſtrologer, and have no more skill then my Chambermaid, or Fannie there.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Truely nor ſo much, for we began to ſmell him out.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: When the fit takes you next to make love, Sir,
Truſt to your merit, and not your ſcience,
That you ſee has deceiv'd you; the match is made now
You ſet all your Engines a work to break.
How ſhallow is this art you brag'd of?
Or, How little are you vers'd in't?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: You told me 'twas but to make trial of me,
Bellamy courted Clarinda, and that
'Twas I he lov'd, when the firſt ſight of him
Proves the contrary; the Stars lend you but
A dimme light, it ſeemes, that can no better
Read our deſtiny by it.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: Did you not perſwade me too, that Celia
Ceas'd to love Bellamy? when Heaven knowes
What torture the continued expreſſions
Of her kindneſs to him, have put me to.
Burn your bookes, Sir, burn your bookes for ſhame,
Your lying bookes.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: 'Tis well for him now, I nere was curious
Enough to peep into my deſtiny,
Nor given that inquiſitive way;
I muſt have had a fling at him too,
Which needes not; there are male-contents enow
To worrie him without me.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: If te Damoiſells have done vit teir tale, pleaſe you have mine, It is a foul tale, I aſſure you, of accuſation againſt tis Aſtrolog too, Did you no promiſe ſend me into France fine new way, and me be here in London ſtill? I be Judge by all te Company, if me no here: and vat is very worſe, you ſay I go wit out Robbing, and begare me looſe my Purſe.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.p: Your grievance is of weight indeed.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: Of veight? gare my grievance be, you make me lighter by all my Money.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: That's eaſily redreſs'd, give him his Purſe agen;
And no more of theſe ſlippery trickes.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: 'Twas but a trick of wit, Sir;
I hope you'l remember the Enſurer, Monſieur.

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: Yes, I aſſure you one halter, if you play more ſuch trick of vit.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Now to my pretty chiders:
For even in that, Ladies, you upbraid me with,
Have I matter enough to make my peace.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: With help of ſome ſtrange hard non ſence,
Your Worſhip's tearmes of Art.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: In plain Engliſh, but firſt your pardon, Sir,
That I durſt play the Aſtrologer with you,
When nere in all my Studies, nor my Travells
I ſpent a ſerious minute to become one.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: You are no Aſtrologer then?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: None, in good ſooth, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: You told me ſo before indeed;
Though my itch of Learning would not let me
Credit it: but now I do believe you▪
He'd nere degrade himſelf in publick thus,
Could he maintain the height
My credulity had rais'd him to.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: And thus may you the better now forgive
The error y'have been in, that ſtill were deaf
To whatſoere I ſaid to diſabuſe you.
If ſooner, Madam, then you durſt expect,
A Father's liking crown your Love, and his,
You may thank me for't; your ma • ch had nere been
Clapt up thus o'th' ſudden, had he not on my
Inſinuation believ'd it made in Heaven.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Truth, I think it had not.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Nor have I done leſs for you, if well conſider'd,
Was it fit ſo fair a ſtock of beauty
Should lie begging of a beggar ſtill?
I ve plac'd you where you'l brighteſt ſhine,
VVhere love with intereſt will be paid you back,
Kiſs for kiſs were poor retaliation.
Bellamy, whom I ſaw adore Clarinda,
VVas not an Idol fit for you to worſhip;
While Gratian's heart became a burning ſacrifice
VVith fire ſhot from your killing eyes.

sp.speaker: Bern.
sp.l: Now he tickle's her.

sp.speaker: Lew.
sp.l: She'l forgive all her enemies
For ſuch another clawing ſpeech.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Let them complain that ſuffer, I have my wiſh;
Nor is your ſhare, I ſee, ſo ſmall in the
Procurement of't, but it has made me yours.
I might have percht in Gratian's Cock-loft ſtill,
But for Aſtrologie.

sp.speaker: Grat.
sp.l: As you have made me no leſs happie, with
As ſincere affection, I vow my ſelf
Your ſervant: yet let me tell you,
I began to think there was not
Much Aſtrologie i'th' buſineſs neither,
What ever we conceited of you.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Happineſs, Gentlemen, is happineſs ſtill,
I take it, which way ſo ere arriv d at.
Something in every deſign we ſtalk with
To take the Vulgar eye, when that which does
The work indeed, being unperceiv'd,
It often is aſcrib'd to a wrong Cauſe.
I deſign'd both theſe matches, Lewis and
Bernard there can witneſs for me,
And to your joyes and mine I ſee 'em made,
Be it with real or fained skill in
What I took upon me, that matter's not.
The pleaſures you reap from it are no fictions,
That we all ſee.
And I expect my thanks accordingly.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: And you, Sir travellour, that were promis'd you ſhould not be robb'd by the way; prythee, how couldſt, if thou hadſt gone thy Journey, when I had ſecur'd thy money here before?

sp.speaker: La-g.
sp.p: Vell, vell, vit one bottle or two de Vine, tis ſhall be ſatisfaction; and ſirrahs, keark you, no tell my maſter, you know vat.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.p: No, no; we would not hang thee.

sp.speaker: Glar.
sp.p: Bellamy might think that were not my felicitie, he has acknowledged you a furtherer of, did I not pay my thanks too; you have oblig'd us both, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.p: If my Compliment be ſomewhat colder, Sir, then others you have had from this thankful Companie, impute it to a certain blindneſs, allows me not yet a full view o'th' happineſs y'have plac'd me in; but as my ſenſe of it increaſes, ſo ſhall my Gratitude.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: I would fain thank you too, Sir; but truly I m beholding t'ee for nothing, but frighting me with the viſion of Bellamy.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Now for our ſqueakers.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.p:
Why I paſs'd for an Aſtrologer, or how, without being one,
I knew enough of your adventures to make th' opinion good a while, Beatrix can partly tell.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: The diſtaff was of Counſel.

sp.speaker: End.
sp.p: The reſt may better come from Lewis there, or Bernard; and be part of their Apologie.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: They in th' Intrigue too?

sp.speaker: End.
sp.l: Grand Intriguers.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.p: All this we'l hear at leaſure; 'twill make an excellent ſtorie, when we have it all together: but now let's in, the air grows cold, though love and youth keep you from feeling it—what fidlers?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Yes in truth, Sir; I ſaw there would be a Wedding or two, and made bold to invite 'em in; there's no mirth without Muſick, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.l: Why God-a-mercy; come, ſtrike up there,
A kiſſing dance to pleaſe theſe Wenches.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: A kiſſing dance! nay then, I will make one,
I'm reſolv'd on't. Come Beatrix.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: You may dance, Sir; but we'l have no kiſſing,
'Tis not come to that yet.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: You are not quite come to 't indeed;
But here are riper lips.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: She tells you true, Sir; 'tis not come to that yet.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Play my delight.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Thy Miſtreſs forbids no kiſſing.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: No, I warrant her.

sp.speaker: Raw.
sp.l: She goes to't with a better ſtomack.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: And they wont kiſs
They ſhall dance by themſelves for Shift.

sp.speaker: Beat.
sp.l: And for Beatrix too.

sp.speaker: Sr Chr.
sp.p: Brisk youths on my credit: come, to ſupper; nothing but welcome can I promiſe though o'th' ſudden; but when my Girl is married
sp.l: I'le feaſt you all, and nobly, that are here;
So your diſlike blaſt not our Wedding cheare.
